verses.english: Then the servant took ten camels from his master's herd and brought with him a selection of his master's finest goods. He then set out for Mesopotamia, traveling toward the city of Nahor.

verses.latin: Cumque implevisset orationem, dixit: Domine Deus domini mei Abraham, occurre, obsecro, hodie mihi, et fac misericordiam cum domino meo Abraham.
verses.english: When he had finished praying, he said: 'Lord, God of my master Abraham, I beg you, grant me success today, and show covenant faithfulness to my master Abraham.'

verses.latin: Ecce ego sto juxta fontem aquae, et filiae civium egredientur ad hauriendam aquam.
verses.english: 'Look, I am standing here beside this well of water, and the daughters of the city's inhabitants will soon come out to draw water.'

verses.latin: Igitur puella, cui ego dixero: Inclina hydriam tuam ut bibam: et illa responderit, Bibe, et camelos tuos etiam potabo: ipsa est quam praeparasti filio tuo Isaac: et per hoc intelligam, quod feceris misericordiam cum domino meo.
verses.english: 'May it be that the young woman to whom I say, "Please lower your jar so I can drink," and who then replies, "Drink, and I will also water your camels"—that she is the one you have prepared for your servant Isaac. By this sign, I will know that you have shown steadfast love to my master.'

verses.latin: Necdum intraverat sermonem, et ecce Rebecca veniebat, filia Bathuel, filii Melchae uxoris Nachor fratris Abraham, habens hydriam in scapula sua.
verses.english: He had barely finished speaking when, behold, Rebekah appeared. She was the daughter of Bethuel, son of Milcah, who was the wife of Nahor, Abraham’s brother. She carried a water jar on her shoulder.

verses.latin: Puella decora nimis, virgo pulcherrima, et incognita viro: descenditque ad fontem, et implevit hydriam, et ascendebat.
verses.english: The young woman was exceptionally beautiful, a pure virgin, and no man had ever been with her. She went down to the spring, filled her jar, and then started to come back up.

verses.latin: Occurritque ei servus, et ait: Da mihi pauxillum aquae ad bibendum de hydria tua.
verses.english: The servant hurried to meet her and said: 'Please, let me drink a little water from your jar.'

verses.latin: Quae respondit: Bibe, domine mi. Festinavitque, et deposuit hydriam super brachium suum, et dedit ei potum.
verses.english: She immediately replied, 'Drink, my lord.' She quickly lowered her jar to her arm and gave him a drink.

verses.latin: Cumque isset potum, ait: Quin et camelis tuis hauriam aquam, donec cuncti bibant.
verses.english: After he had finished drinking, she said: 'I will also draw water for your camels until they have all had enough to drink.'

verses.latin: Et effudit hydriam in canalibus, et cucurrit rursum ad puteum ut hauriret aquam, et haurivit cunctis camelis ejus.
verses.english: So she quickly emptied her jar into the watering trough, and then ran back to the well to draw more water, and she continued drawing for all his camels.

verses.latin: Vir autem ille contemplabatur eam tacitus, scire volens an prosperum iter fecisset Dominus, an non.
verses.english: The man watched her in silence, wanting to know if the Lord had truly made his journey successful, or not.

verses.latin: Postquam ergo biberunt cameli, protulit vir inaures aureas duos, pensantes siclos duos: et armillas totidem ad mensuram siclorum aureos decem.
verses.english: After the camels had finished drinking, the man took out two gold nose rings, together weighing two shekels, and two gold bracelets, weighing ten shekels.

verses.latin: Et dixit ad eam: Cujus es filia? indica mihi: est in domo patris tui locus ad mansitandum nobis?
verses.english: Then he asked her, 'Whose daughter are you? Please tell me: Is there room in your father's house for us to spend the night?'

verses.latin: Respondit: Filia Bathuelis sum, filii Melchae, quem peperit Nachor.
verses.english: She answered, 'I am the daughter of Bethuel, son of Milcah, whom she bore to Nahor.'

verses.latin: Addiditque, dicens: Pabulam et foenum plurimum est apud nos, et spatia ad pernoctandum.
verses.english: She added, saying: 'We have plenty of straw and fodder, and also space for you to spend the night.'

verses.latin: Inclinavit se homo, et adoravit Dominum,
verses.english: The man bowed his head and worshipped the Lord,

verses.latin: dicens: Benedictus Dominus Deus domini mei Abraham, qui non abstulit misericordiam suam et veritatem suam a domino meo: et recto itinere me perduxit in domum fratris domini mei.
verses.english: saying: 'Blessed be the Lord, the God of my master Abraham, who has not withheld His covenant faithfulness and His truth from my master. He has led me directly to the house of my master's brother!'

verses.latin: Cucurrit itaque puella, et nuntiavit in domo matris suae omnia quae audierat.
verses.english: So the young woman ran off and reported everything she had heard in her mother's household.

verses.latin: Habebat autem Rebecca fratrem nomine Laban, qui festinus egressus est ad hominem, foras ubi fons erat.
verses.english: Now Rebekah had a brother named Laban, and he quickly rushed out to the man at the spring.

verses.latin: Cumque vidisset inaures et armillas in manibus sororis suae, et audisset omnia verba referentis, venis ad hominem, qui stabat juxta camelos, et prope fontem aquae.
verses.english: When he saw the nose rings and bracelets on his sister's hands, and heard all the words she recounted, he came to the man who was still standing by the camels, near the water spring.

verses.latin: Et ait: Ingrederere, benedicte Domini: cur foris stas? praeparavi domum, et locum camelis tuis.
verses.english: And he said, 'Come in, blessed of the Lord! Why are you standing outside? I have prepared the house, and a place for your camels.'

verses.latin: Introduxitque virum in domum: et camelos stravit, deditque paleas et foenum camelis, et aquam ad lavandos pedes ejus, et virorum qui venerant cum eo.
verses.english: So Laban brought the man into the house. He then unloaded the camels, gave straw and fodder to the camels, and provided water for washing his feet and the feet of the men who had come with him.

verses.latin: Propositoque illi cibo, ait: Non comedam, donec loquar sermones meos. Respondit ei: Loquere.
verses.english: When food was set before him, he said, 'I will not eat until I have spoken my message.' Laban replied to him, 'Speak.'

verses.latin: At ille: Servus, inquit, Abraham sum.
verses.english: Then he said, 'I am Abraham's servant.'

verses.latin: Et Dominus benedixit domino meo valde, et magnificatus est: et dedit ei oves et boves, argentum et aurum, servos et ancillas, camelos et asinos.
verses.english: And the Lord has greatly blessed my master, so that he has become very prosperous. He has given him flocks and herds, silver and gold, male and female servants, camels and donkeys.

verses.latin: Peperitque Sara uxor domini mei filium domino meo, postquam jam esset anus: deditque illi omnia quae habebat.
verses.english: And Sarah, my master's wife, bore a son to my master, even after she was already old. My master has given everything he owns to that son.

verses.latin: Et adjuravit me dominus meus, dicens: Non accipies uxorem filio meo de filiabus Chanaan, in quorum terra habito:
verses.english: My master made me swear an oath, saying: 'You must not choose a wife for my son from the daughters of the Canaanites, in whose land I am living;'

verses.latin: sed ad domum patris mei perges, et de cognatione mea accipies uxorem filio meo.
verses.english: 'but you are to go to my father's house, and choose a wife for my son from among my relatives.'

verses.latin: Egoque respondi domino meo: Quid si venire noluerit mulier mecum?
verses.english: And I said to my master, 'What if the woman is unwilling to come with me?'

verses.latin: Respondit: Dominus, in cujus conspectu ambulo, mittet angelum suum tecum, et diriget viam tuam: et accipies uxorem filio meo de cognatione mea, et de domo patris mei.
verses.english: He replied, 'The Lord, in whose presence I live and walk, will send His angel with you and will make your journey successful. And you will find a wife for my son from my own relatives and from my father's household.'

verses.latin: Abiit autem rursum Abraham et duxit uxorem nomine Cetura.
verses.english: Abraham, for his part, married again, and took a wife named Keturah.

verses.latin: Quae genuit illi Zamran et Jecsan et Madan et Madian et Jesboc et Sue.
verses.english: She bore for him Zamran, Jecsan, Madan, Madian, Jesboc, and Sue.

verses.latin: Jecsan quoque genuit Saba et Dadan. Filii Dadan fuerunt Rassum et Lugum et Lemin.
verses.english: Jecsan, for his part, begot Saba and Dadan. The sons of Dadan were Rassum, Lugum, and Lemin.

verses.latin: Porro filii Madian: Epha et Opher et Henoch et Abida et Eldaa. Omnes hi filii Ceturae.
verses.english: Furthermore, the sons of Madian were Epha, Opher, Henoch, Abida, and Eldaa. All these were descendants through Keturah.

verses.latin: Deditque Abraham cuncta quae possidebat Isaac.
verses.english: And Abraham gave all that he possessed to Isaac.

verses.latin: Filiis autem concubinarum largitus est munera, et separavit eos ab Isaac filio suo, dum adhuc viveret, ad plagam orientalem.
verses.english: But to the sons of his concubines, he gave gifts, and he separated them from Isaac, his son, while he was still living, sending them toward the eastern region.

verses.latin: Fuerunt autem dies vitae Abrahae, quos vixit, centum septuaginta quinque anni.
verses.english: Now the days of Abraham's life, which he lived, were one hundred seventy-five years.

verses.latin: Et consummatus, mortuus est in senectute bona, plenus dierum, et aggregatus est ad populum suum.
verses.english: And being fully aged, he died in a good old age, full of days, and was gathered to his people.

verses.latin: Et sepelierunt eum Isaac et Ismahel filii sui in spelunca Machpela, quae sita est ex adverso Mambre in agro Ephron filii Seor Hethei,
verses.english: And Isaac and Ishmael, his sons, buried him in the cave of Machpelah, which is situated opposite Mamre, in the field of Ephron, the son of Seor the Hethite.

verses.latin: quam emerat Abraham a filiis Heth: ibi sepultus est ipse et Sarra uxor ejus.
verses.english: Abraham had purchased this cave from the sons of Heth: there he was buried, and Sarah his wife.

verses.latin: Et post obitum illius benedixit Deus Isaac filio ejus: qui habitavit juxta puteum Visionis.
verses.english: And after his death, God blessed Isaac, his son. Isaac then lived near the Well of Vision.

verses.latin: Hae sunt generationes Ismahel filii Abrahae, quem genuit Agar Aegyptia Sarrae famula ipsi Abrahae.
verses.english: These are the generations of Ishmael, Abraham’s son, whom Hagar the Egyptian, Sarah’s handmaid, bore to Abraham.

verses.latin: Et haec nomina filiorum Ismahel per vocabula et generationes eorum: primogenitus Ismahel Nabajoth, et Cedar, et Adbeel, et Masma,
verses.english: And these are the names of Ishmael's sons, according to their names and their generations: Ishmael’s firstborn was Nabajoth, then Cedar, Adbeel, Masma,

verses.latin: et Massa, et Iduma, et Massa,
verses.english: and Massa, and Iduma, and Massa (this is a repeated name or variant spelling in the text),

verses.latin: et Badad, et Thema, et Jetur, et Naphis, et Cedma.
verses.english: and Badad, and Thema, and Jetur, and Naphis, and Cedma.

verses.latin: Hi sunt filii Ismahel, et haec nomina per oppida et castella eorum duodecim principes tribuum suarum.
verses.english: These are the sons of Ishmael, and these are their names by their towns and their encampments—twelve princes of their tribes.

verses.latin: Et facti sunt anni vitae Ismahel centum triginta septem, et deficiens mortuus est, et aggregatus ad populum suum.
verses.english: And the years of Ishmael’s life were one hundred thirty-seven. He then weakened, died, and was gathered to his people.

verses.latin: A Havila Emath usque dum veniatur Sur, quae respicit Aegyptum incedentibus Assyriis: coram omnibus fratribus suis obiit.
verses.english: From Havila to Hemath, as far as one comes to Sur, which faces Egypt as one journeys towards the Assyrians—he died in the presence of all his brethren.

verses.latin: Hae quoque sunt generationes Isaac filii Abraham: Abraham genuit Isaac.
verses.english: These also are the generations of Isaac, Abraham’s son: Abraham begot Isaac.

verses.latin: Cumque factus esset Isaac annorum quadraginta, duxit uxorem Rebeccam filiam Bathuel Syri de Mesopotamia, sororem Laban Syri.
verses.english: When Isaac was forty years old, he married Rebecca, the daughter of Bathuel the Syrian from Mesopotamia, the sister of Laban the Syrian.

verses.latin: Deprecatusque est Isaac Dominum pro uxore sua, eo quod esset sterilis: qui exaudivit eum, et conceptit Rebecca uxorem illius.
verses.english: Isaac then implored the Lord for his wife, because she was barren. The Lord heard him, and Rebecca, his wife, conceived.

verses.latin: Sed impetu collidebantur in utero. Quae ait: Si sic mihi futurum erat, quid necesse fuit concipere? Et abiit ut consuleret Dominum.
verses.english: But the children struggled violently within her womb. She said, “If this is how it will be for me, why was it necessary to conceive?” And she went to consult the Lord.

verses.latin: Respondensque Dominus: Duae gentes in utero tuo sunt, et duo populi ex ventre tuo dividentur, et populus populum superabit, et major minori serviet.
verses.english: And the Lord responded: “Two nations are in your womb, and two peoples will be divided from your body. One people will overcome the other people, and the older will serve the younger.”

verses.latin: Jam tempus pariendi advenerat, et ecce gemini in utero ejus.
verses.english: When the time for her to give birth arrived, behold, there were twins in her womb.

verses.latin: Qui primus egressus est, rufus erat, et totus in similitudinem pellis hispidus: vocatumque est nomen ejus Esau.
verses.english: The first one who came out was reddish, and entirely hairy like a cloak. And his name was called Esau.

verses.latin: Post hunc egressus est frater ejus, cujus manus apprehendit calcaneum Esau: et idcirco vocatum est nomen ejus Jacob. Sexagenarius erat Isaac quando nati sunt ei.
verses.english: After him came his brother, whose hand grasped Esau’s heel. And therefore, his name was called Jacob. Isaac was sixty years old when they were born to him.

verses.latin: Creverunt autem pueri: factusque est Esau vir gnarus venandi, et homo agri: Jacob vero vir simplex habitans in tabernaculis.
verses.english: Now the boys grew up. Esau became a skilled hunter, a man of the field. Jacob, however, was a simple man, dwelling in tents.

verses.latin: Isaac amabat Esau, eo quod comedebat de venationibus illius: et Rebecca diligebat Jacob.
verses.english: Isaac loved Esau, because he ate of his game. And Rebecca loved Jacob.

verses.latin: Coxit autem Jacob pulmentum: ad quem cum venisset Esau de agro lassus,
verses.english: Now Jacob cooked a stew. And when Esau came in from the field, weary,

verses.latin: ait: Da mihi de coctura ista rufa, quia vehementer enutritus sum. Ob quam causam vocatum est nomen ejus Edom.
verses.english: he said, “Give me some of that red dish, for I am extremely famished.” For this reason, his name was called Edom (meaning 'red').

verses.latin: Cui dixit Jacob: Vende mihi ante haec primogenita tua.
verses.english: To him Jacob said, “Sell me your birthright first.”

verses.latin: Ille respondit: En morior, quid mihi proderunt primogenita?
verses.english: He replied, “Look, I am about to die. What good will a birthright be to me?”

verses.latin: Dixitque Jacob: Jura ergo mihi. Juravit Esau, et vendidit primogenita sua Jacob.
verses.english: And Jacob said, “Swear to me then.” Esau swore, and sold his birthright to Jacob.

verses.latin: Et sic panem et lentis cocturam dedit ei: qui comedit, et bibit, et surrexit, et abiit: parvipendens quod primogenita vendidisset.
verses.english: And so, Jacob gave him bread and the lentil stew. Esau ate, and drank, and rose up, and went away, showing little regard for having sold his birthright.

verses.latin: Accidit autem fames in terra post eam sterilitatem quae acciderat in diebus Abrahae: et abiit Isaac ad Abimelech regem Palestinorum in Gerara.
verses.english: Now a famine occurred in the land, following the previous famine that had occurred in the days of Abraham. And Isaac went to Abimelech, the king of the Philistines, in Gerar.

verses.latin: Apparuitque ei Dominus, et ait: Noli descendere in Aegyptum, sed commorare in terra quam tibi dixero.
verses.english: And the Lord appeared to him and said, “Do not go down to Egypt, but remain in the land which I will tell you about.

verses.latin: Pergrinare in ea, et ero tecum, et benedicam tibi: tibi enim et semini tuo dabo universas regiones has, complens juramentum quod juravi Abraham patri tuo.
verses.english: Journey as a stranger in this land, and I will be with you, and I will bless you. For to you and to your offspring I will give all these regions, fulfilling the oath which I swore to Abraham your father.

verses.latin: Et multiplicabo semen tuum sicut stellas caeli: et dabo posteris tuis universas regiones istas: et benedicentur in semine tuo omnes gentes terrae,
verses.english: And I will multiply your offspring like the stars of the sky. And I will give all these regions to your descendants. And all the nations of the earth will be blessed through your offspring,

verses.latin: eo quod obedierit Abraham voci meae, et custodierit praecepta et mandata mea, et caeremonias ritusque servaverit.
verses.english: because Abraham obeyed My voice, and kept My precepts and My commandments, and observed My ceremonies and rituals.”

verses.latin: Mansit itaque Isaac in Gerara.
verses.english: So Isaac remained in Gerar.

verses.latin: Facta est autem fames in terra post illam famem quae acciderat sub Abraham; et abiit Isaac ad Abimelech regem Palaestinorum in Gerara.
verses.english: Now there was a famine in the land—a new one, after the previous famine that had happened during the time of Abraham. And so Isaac went to Abimelech, the king of the Philistines, in Gerar.

verses.latin: Apparuitque ei Dominus, et ait: Ne descendas in Aegyptum, sed commorare in terra quam monstravero tibi.
verses.english: And the Lord appeared to Isaac, saying: 'Do not go down to Egypt; instead, stay in the land that I will show you.'

verses.latin: Et peregrinare in ea, eroque tecum, et benedicam tibi: tibi enim et semini tuo dabo universas regiones istas, complens juramentum quod juravi Abraham patri tuo.
verses.english: Live as a temporary resident in this land, and I will be with you, and I will bless you. For to you and to your descendants, I will give all these lands, fulfilling the oath that I swore to Abraham, your father.

verses.latin: Et multiplicabo semen tuum sicut stellas caeli: et dabo semini tuo universas regiones istas: et benedicentur in semine tuo omnes gentes terrae,
verses.english: And I will multiply your descendants, making them as numerous as the stars of the sky. And I will give all these lands to your descendants. And through your offspring, all the nations of the earth will be blessed,

verses.latin: eo quod obedierit Abraham voci meae, et custodierit praecepta et mandata mea, et caeremonias ritusque servarit.
verses.english: because Abraham obeyed My voice, and kept My commands and My ordinances, and observed My ceremonies and rituals.

verses.latin: Mansit itaque Isaac in Gerara.
verses.english: So Isaac remained in Gerar.

verses.latin: Cumque interrogassent eum pastores loci illius super uxore sua, respondit: Soror mea est: timuerat enim confiteri quod sibi esset matrimonio juncta, cogitans ne forte interficerent eum propter illius pulchritudinem.
verses.english: When the men of that place asked him about his wife, he replied, 'She is my sister.' For he was afraid to admit that she was his wife by marriage, thinking that they might kill him because of her great beauty.

verses.latin: Cumque pertransissent dies plurimi, et illic demoraretur, prospiciens Abimelech rex Palaestinorum per fenestram, vidit Isaac ludentem cum Rebecca uxore sua.
verses.english: After many days had passed, and while he was living there, Abimelech, the king of the Philistines, looked out through a window and saw Isaac caressing Rebecca, his wife.

verses.latin: Et accersito Isaac, ait: Manifestum est quod uxor tua sit: cur mentitus es eam sororem tuam esse? Respondit: Timui ne morerer propter illam.
verses.english: And calling Isaac, he said to him: 'It is clear that she is your wife. Why did you lie, saying she was your sister?' Isaac replied, 'I was afraid that I might die because of her.'

verses.latin: Et ait Abimelech: Quid hoc fecisti nobis? potuit aliquis de populo meo concumbere cum uxore tua, et induxisses super nos crimen magnum.
verses.english: And Abimelech said: 'What is this that you have done to us? Any one of my people could have slept with your wife, and you would have brought great guilt upon us.'

verses.latin: Et praecepit omni populo, dicens: Qui tetigerit virum hunc, et uxorem ejus, morte morietur.
verses.english: And he commanded all his people, saying: 'Whoever touches this man or his wife will surely be put to death.'

verses.latin: Sevit autem Isaac in terra illa, et invenit in ipso anno centuplum: et benedixit ei Dominus.
verses.english: Now Isaac sowed seed in that land, and in that same year, he harvested a hundredfold. And the Lord blessed him abundantly.

verses.latin: Magnificatusque est homo, et ibat proficiens atque succrescens, donec vehementissimus fieret.
verses.english: And the man became great, and he continued to prosper and grow, until he became very wealthy and powerful.

verses.latin: Habebat autem possessionem ovium, et armentorum, et familiae multae. Invidebant igitur ei Palaestini.
verses.english: For he possessed many flocks of sheep, and herds of cattle, and a large household of servants. Therefore, the Philistines envied him.

verses.latin: Omnes puteos quos foderant servi patris illius Abraham, Abimelech obstruxit implens humo:
verses.english: All the wells that the servants of his father, Abraham, had dug, Abimelech had stopped up by filling them with earth.

verses.latin: ad extremum ipsum Isaac admonuit, ut abiret ab eo, dicens: Recede a nobis, quoniam potentior nobis factus es valde.
verses.english: Finally, he warned Isaac himself to leave his territory, saying: 'Go away from us, for you have become much too powerful for us.'

verses.latin: Migravit itaque inde Isaac, et tabernaculis fixis in torrente Gerarae, habitabat ibi.
verses.english: So Isaac moved away from there, and after setting up his tents in the valley of Gerar, he lived there.

verses.latin: Rursum effodit puteos quos foderant diebus Abraham patris sui, et quos, post obitum illius, obstruxerant Philisthim: appellavitque eos iisdem nominibus quibus ante pater vocaverat.
verses.english: He again dug out the wells that had been dug in the days of his father Abraham, and which the Philistines had stopped up after Abraham's death. And he called them by the same names that his father had called them before.

verses.latin: Foderuntque in torrente servi Isaac, et repererunt aquam vivam.
verses.english: And Isaac's servants dug in the valley, and they found a well of flowing water.

verses.latin: Sed et illic jurgium fuit pastorum Gerarae adversum pastores Isaac, dicentium: Nostra est aqua. Unde nomen putei illius, Calumnia, eo quod calumniati essent ei.
verses.english: But even there, the herdsmen of Gerar quarreled with Isaac's herdsmen, saying, 'The water is ours!' Therefore, he named that well 'Quarrel', because they had disputed with him there.

verses.latin: Foderunt quoque alterum puteum: et pro illo quoque rixati sunt: vocavitque nomen ejus, Inimicitias.
verses.english: They also dug another well, and they quarreled over that one as well. So he named it 'Enmity'.

verses.latin: Profectus inde, fodit alterum puteum: pro quo non est contentus: idcirco vocavit nomen ejus, Latitudo, dicens: Nunc dilatavit Dominus et fecit spatio locum, ut crescamus in terra.
verses.english: Moving on from there, he dug another well, and for this one, there was no contention. Therefore, he named it 'Broad Places', saying: 'Now the Lord has made room for us, and given us a spacious place, so that we may flourish and increase in the land.'

verses.latin: Ascendit autem de illo loco in Bersabee.
verses.english: From that place, he went up to Beersheba.

verses.latin: Apparuitque ei Dominus in ipsa nocte, dicens: Ego sum Deus Abraham patris tui: noli timere, quia tecum sum: benedicam tibi, et multiplicabo semen tuum propter Abraham servum meum.
verses.english: And the Lord appeared to him on that very night, saying: 'I am the God of Abraham, your father. Do not be afraid, for I am with you. I will bless you and multiply your descendants for the sake of Abraham, My servant.'

verses.latin: Aedificavit ergo ibi altare: et invocato nomine Domini, extendit tabernaculum suum: praecepitque servis suis ut foderent puteum.
verses.english: So he built an altar there, and called upon the name of the Lord. Then he pitched his tent there, and his servants dug a well.

verses.latin: Ad quem de Geraris Abimelech venit, et Ochozath amicus illius, et Phicol princeps militiae.
verses.english: And Abimelech came to him from Gerar, along with Ahuzzath, his friend, and Phicol, the commander of his army.

verses.latin: Dixitque eis Isaac: Quid venistis ad me hominem quem odistis, et expulistis a vobis?
verses.english: And Isaac said to them: 'Why have you come to me, a man whom you hated, and whom you drove away from among you?'

verses.latin: Qui responderunt: Vidimus tecum esse Dominum, et idcirco locuti sumus: Fiat pactum inter nos et te, et percutiamus foedus,
verses.english: They replied: 'We clearly saw that the Lord is with you, and therefore we said to ourselves: "Let there now be an oath between us and you, and let us make a covenant together," – an agreement of peace.'

verses.latin: ut non facias nobis quicquam mali, sicut et nos nihil maluimus contra te: sed cum pace dimisimus te, auctum Domini benedictione.
verses.english: 'that you will do us no harm, just as we intended no harm against you. Instead, we sent you away in peace, because you were greatly blessed by the Lord.'

verses.latin: Fecit ergo eis convivium, et comederunt et biberunt.
verses.english: So Isaac prepared a feast for them, and they ate and drank.

verses.latin: Surgentesque mane, juraverunt sibi mutuo: et dimisit eos Isaac, qui reversi sunt in loca sua.
verses.english: And rising early in the morning, they swore an oath to one another. Then Isaac sent them away, and they returned to their own land.

verses.latin: Eodem autem die venerunt servi Isaac, nuntiantes ei de puteo quem foderant, atque dicentes: Invenimus aquam.
verses.english: On that very same day, Isaac's servants came to tell him about the well they had dug, saying, 'We have found water!'

verses.latin: Appellavitque illum Abundantiam: et de nomine civitas appellata est Bersabee, usque in praesentem diem.
verses.english: And he called it 'Abundance'. Therefore, the city was called Beersheba from that name, even to this present day.

verses.latin: Factus est autem Esau quadraginta annorum, accepit uxores Judith filiam Beeri Hethei, et Basemath filiam Elon Hethei.
verses.english: Now when Esau was forty years old, he took wives: Judith, the daughter of Beeri the Hittite, and Basemath, the daughter of Elon the Hittite.

verses.latin: Quae ambae offenderant animum Isaac et Rebeccae.
verses.english: Both of whom caused bitterness and sorrow to the spirit of Isaac and Rebecca.

verses.latin: Factum est autem postquam senuerat Isaac, et caligaverant oculi ejus, et videre non poterat: vocavit Esau filium suum primogenitum, et dixit illi: Fili mi.
verses.english: Now it came to pass, when Isaac had become old and his eyes had grown so dim that he could no longer see, he called Esau, his firstborn son, and said to him: 'My son.'

verses.latin: Qui respondit: Adsum. Dixitque Isaac: Ecce inveteravi, et ignoro diem mortis meæ.
verses.english: Esau answered: 'Here I am.' Isaac then said: 'Look, I am now an old man, and I do not know the day of my death.'

verses.latin: Sume arma tua, pharetram et arcum, et egredere foras: cumque venatu aliquid apprehenderis,
verses.english: Therefore, take your hunting weapons—your quiver and your bow—and go out into the field. When you catch something by hunting,

verses.latin: fac mihi inde pulmentum, sicut scis me velle, et affer ut comedam: et benedicat tibi anima mea, antequam moriar.
verses.english: make me a stew from it, just as you know I like it, and bring it to me, so I may eat. After that, my soul will bless you before I die.

verses.latin: Rebecca vero audierat, cum loqueretur Isaac ad Esau filium suum. Quo profecto in campum ut venaretur, et quod ceperat afferret:
verses.english: Rebecca, however, had overheard when Isaac spoke to Esau, his son. So when Esau had gone out into the field to hunt and bring back what he had caught,

verses.latin: dixit ad Jacob filium suum: Audivi patrem tuum loquentem cum fratre tuo Esau, et dicentem:
verses.english: Rebecca said to Jacob, her son: 'I heard your father speaking with your brother Esau, saying:'

verses.latin: Affer mihi de venatione tua, et fac cibos ut comedam, et benedicam tibi coram Domino antequam moriar.
verses.english: 'Bring me some of your game, and make me a meal so I may eat it, and then I will bless you before the Lord before I die.'

verses.latin: Nunc ergo, fili mi, acquiesce consiliis meis, quæ tibi præcipio.
verses.english: 'Now therefore, my son, listen to my counsel, which I am commanding you to follow.'

verses.latin: Pergens ad gregem, affer mihi duos hedos optimos, ut faciam ex illis escas patri tuo, quibus libenter vescitur:
verses.english: 'Go to the flock and bring me two of the best young goats, so I may prepare a meal from them for your father, the kind he enjoys eating.'

verses.latin: quas cum intuleris, et comederit, benedicat tibi antequam moriatur.
verses.english: 'When you bring them in and he eats them, he will bless you before he dies.'

verses.latin: Cui Jacob respondit: Nostri Esau frater meus homo pilosus est, et ego lenis.
verses.english: Jacob answered her: 'You know my brother Esau is a hairy man, but I have smooth skin.'

verses.latin: Si attrectaverit me pater meus, et senserit, timeo ne putet me velle illudere sibi, et inducam super me maledictionem, et non benedictionem.
verses.english: 'If my father touches me and feels my skin, I am afraid he will think I am trying to deceive him, and then I will bring a curse upon myself instead of a blessing.'

verses.latin: Ad quem mater: In me sit, inquit, ista maledictio, fili mi: tantum audi vocem meam, et pergens affer quæ dixi.
verses.english: His mother said to him: 'Upon me be that curse, my son. Only listen to my voice and go and bring what I have told you.'

verses.latin: Abiit, et attulit, deditque matri. Quæ paravit cibos, sicut velle sciebat patrem illius.
verses.english: So he went and brought them and gave them to his mother. She then prepared the food, just as she knew his father liked it.

verses.latin: Et vestibus Esau, optimis, quas apud se habebat domi, induit eum: et pelliculas hædorum circumdedit manibus, et fœminei colli nudaverat longitudinem.
verses.english: Then she dressed Jacob in Esau's best clothes, which she kept with her in the house. She also covered his hands and the smooth part of his neck with the skins of the young goats.

verses.latin: Dixitque ad eum: Affer patri tuo, ut comedens benedicat tibi.
verses.english: She said to him: 'Bring this to your father, so that when he eats, he may bless you.'

verses.latin: At ille intulit patri. Qui cum comedisset, ait: Quis es tu, fili mi?
verses.english: So he brought it to his father. When Isaac had eaten, he said: 'Who are you, my son?'

verses.latin: Respondit Jacob: Ego sum Esau primogenitus tuus: feci sicut præcepisti mihi: surge, sede, et comede de venatione mea, ut benedicat mihi anima tua.
verses.english: Jacob answered: 'I am Esau, your firstborn. I have done as you commanded me. Rise up, sit down, and eat of my game, so that your soul may bless me.'

verses.latin: Dixitque Isaac: Quomodo, fili mi, tam cito invenire potuisti?
verses.english: Isaac said: 'How is it, my son, that you were able to find it so quickly?'

verses.latin: Qui respondit: Voluntas Dei fuit ut cito occurreret mihi quod volebam.
verses.english: Jacob answered: 'It was God's will that what I sought quickly came before me.'

verses.latin: Dixitque Isaac: Accede huc, ut tangam te, fili mi, et probem utrum tu sis Esau an non.
verses.english: Isaac said: 'Come closer here, so that I may touch you, my son, and determine whether you are truly Esau or not.'

verses.latin: Accessit Jacob ad patrem suum: et palpato eo, dixit Isaac: Vox quidem, vocem Jacob est: sed manus, manus sunt Esau.
verses.english: Jacob came closer to his father. Isaac, having felt him, said: 'The voice, indeed, is the voice of Jacob, but the hands are the hands of Esau.'

verses.latin: Et non cognovit eum, quia pilosæ manus æmulabantur majoris pellibus. Benedixitque illi.
verses.english: And he did not recognize him, because his hairy hands resembled those of his elder son Esau. So Isaac blessed him.

verses.latin: Et ait: Tu es filius meus Esau?
verses.english: And he said: 'Are you truly my son Esau?'

verses.latin: Respondit: Ego sum. Tunc ait: Affer mihi, ut comedam de venatione tua, fili mi, et benedicat tibi anima mea.
verses.english: Jacob answered: 'I am.' Then Isaac said: 'Bring it to me, so I may eat of your game, my son, and my soul may bless you.'

verses.latin: Cumque oblatum comedisset, protulit et vinum: quo hausto,
verses.english: When Jacob brought it and Isaac had eaten, Isaac then brought out wine. After he had drunk it,

verses.latin: dixit ei: Accede ad me, et osculare me, fili mi.
verses.english: he said to Jacob: 'Come near me and kiss me, my son.'

verses.latin: Accessit, et osculatus est eum. Statimque ut sensit vestimentorum illius fragrantiam, benedicens illi, ait: Ecce odor filii mei sicut odor agri pleni, cui benedixit Dominus.
verses.english: Jacob came near and kissed him. As soon as Isaac smelled the fragrance of his garments, he blessed him and said: 'Look, the smell of my son is like the smell of a field full of crops, a field which the Lord has blessed.'

verses.latin: Det tibi Deus de rore cæli, et de pinguedine terræ, abundantiam frumenti, et vini.
verses.english: 'May God give you of the dew of the sky and of the richness of the earth, an abundance of grain and of new wine.'

verses.latin: Et serviant tibi populi, et adorent te tribus: esto dominus fratrum tuorum, et incurventur ante te filii matris tuæ.
verses.english: 'May peoples serve you, and tribes bow down before you. Be lord over your brothers, and may your mother's sons bow down before you.'

verses.latin: Qui maledixerit tibi, sit maledictus: et qui benedixerit tibi, benedictionibus repleatur.
verses.english: 'Whoever curses you, let him be cursed; and whoever blesses you, let him be filled with blessings.'

verses.latin: Vix Isaac completis sermonibus, et egressus Jacob foras, venit Esau, reversus de venatione.
verses.english: Scarcely had Isaac finished speaking these words, and Jacob had just gone out, when Esau arrived, returning from his hunt.

verses.latin: Paratisque optimis cibis, intulit patri, dicens: Surge pater mi, et comede de venatione filii tui, ut benedicat mihi anima tua.
verses.english: After preparing a fine meal, he brought it to his father, saying: 'Arise, my father, and eat of your son's game, so that your soul may bless me.'

verses.latin: Expavit Isaac vehementer, et ultra quam credi potest admirans, ait: Quis igitur ille est, qui dudum apportavit mihi venationem, et comedi omnia priusquam tu venires? et benedixi illi: eritque benedictus.
verses.english: Isaac was utterly terrified, and amazed beyond belief, saying: 'Who then was it who just now brought me game, and I ate everything before you came? And I blessed him — and he will remain blessed.'

verses.latin: Auditis Esau sermonibus patris, irrugiit clamore magno, et amaro: et dixit: Benedic etiam et mihi, pater mi.
verses.english: When Esau heard his father's words, he cried out with a loud and bitter cry, and said: 'Bless me too, my father!'

verses.latin: At ille ait: Frater tuus supplantavit me fraudulenter, et accepit benedictionem tuam.
verses.english: But Isaac said: 'Your brother came deceitfully and took away your blessing.'

verses.latin: Respondit Esau: Justo nomine appellatus est Jacob: supplantavit enim me jam altero tempore: primogenita mea ante tulit, et nunc secundo benedictionem meam abstulit. Et rursus ad patrem: Numquid non reservasti et mihi benedictionem?
verses.english: Esau answered: 'He is rightly named Jacob, for he has now supplanted me a second time. First he took away my birthright, and now he has taken away my blessing too!' And again he said to his father: 'Have you not reserved a blessing for me as well?'

verses.latin: Respondit Isaac: Dominum tuum illum constitui, et omnes fratres ejus ei servituti subjeci: frumento et vino stabilivi eum. Et tibi, quid ultra facere potero, fili mi?
verses.english: Isaac answered: 'I have made him your master, and all his brothers I have subjected to his service. I have sustained him with grain and wine. And for you, my son, what more can I do?'

verses.latin: Cui Esau: Numquid una, inquit, tantum est benedictio tibi, pater? Mihi quoque obsecro, ut benedicas. Cumque ejularet, et fleret,
verses.english: Esau said to him: 'Have you only one blessing, father? Please, bless me also.' And as he wailed and wept,

verses.latin: commotus Isaac, ait illi: In pinguedine terræ, et in rore cæli desuper erit benedictio tua.
verses.english: Isaac was moved and said to him: 'Behold, your blessing shall be from the richness of the earth and from the dew of the sky above.'

verses.latin: Vocavit itaque Isaac Jacob et benedixit, et praecepit ei dicens: Ne accipias uxorem de genere Chanaan:
verses.english: So Isaac called Jacob, and he gave Jacob his blessing. Then Isaac gave Jacob a command, saying: "Do not take a wife from the people of Canaan."

verses.latin: sed vade et peregrinare in Mesopotamia Syriae, ad domum Bathuel patris matris tuae, et accipe tibi inde uxorem de filiabus Laban avunculi tui.
verses.english: Instead, go and journey to Mesopotamia in Syria, to the house of Bethuel, your mother’s father. From there, take a wife for yourself from among the daughters of Laban, your uncle.

verses.latin: Et Deus omnipotens benedicat tibi, et crescere te faciat, et multiplicet, ut sis in turbas populorum:
verses.english: And may Almighty God bless you, cause you to grow, and make you fruitful, so that you may become a vast assembly of peoples.

verses.latin: et det tibi benedictiones Abrahae, et semini tuo post te: ut possideas terram peregrinationis tuae, quam pollicitus est avo tuo.
verses.english: And may He give you the blessings that Abraham received, and to your descendants after you. This is so you may possess the land where you are a sojourner—the land He promised to your grandfather, Abraham.

verses.latin: Cumque dimisisset Isaac Jacob, abiit in Mesopotamiam Syriae, ad Laban filium Bathuel Syrum, fratrem Rebeccae matris suae.
verses.english: So after Isaac had sent Jacob away, Jacob went to Mesopotamia in Syria, to Laban, the son of Bethuel the Aramean, who was the brother of Rebecca, Jacob's mother.

verses.latin: Videns autem Esau, quod benedixisset pater suus Jacob, et misisset eum in Mesopotamiam Syriae, ut inde uxorem duceret, et quod post benedictionem praecepisset ei, dicens: Non accipias uxorem de filiabus Chanaan:
verses.english: Now Esau saw that his father had blessed Jacob and sent him to Mesopotamia in Syria to get a wife from there. He also heard that after the blessing, Isaac had commanded Jacob, saying: "Do not take a wife from the daughters of Canaan."

verses.latin: et quod obedierat Jacob parentibus suis, et isset in Mesopotamiam Syriae.
verses.english: Esau also saw that Jacob had obeyed his parents and had gone to Mesopotamia in Syria.

verses.latin: Intellegens itaque Esau quod non placuerant patri suo filiae Chanaan,
verses.english: So Esau understood that the daughters of Canaan were not pleasing to his father, Isaac.

verses.latin: abiit ad Ismael, et duxit uxorem praeter eas, quas prius habebat, Maheleth filiam Ismael filii Abrahae sororem Nabaioth.
verses.english: Therefore, Esau went to Ishmael and took Mahalath, the daughter of Ishmael, Abraham’s son, and the sister of Nebaioth, as a wife in addition to the wives he already had.

verses.latin: Profectus ergo Jacob de Bersabee, pergebat Haran.
verses.english: So Jacob set out from Beersheba and traveled towards Haran.

verses.latin: Cumque venisset ad quemdam locum, in quo pernoctare voluit post solis occubitum, tulit de lapidibus qui jacebant, et supponens capiti suo, dormivit in eodem loco.
verses.english: When he came to a certain place where he intended to spend the night because the sun had set, he took one of the stones lying there, placed it under his head, and lay down to sleep in that same spot.

verses.latin: Viditque in somnis scalam stantem super terram, et cacumen illius tangens caelum: angelos quoque Dei ascendentes et descendentes per illam,
verses.english: Then he had a dream: he saw a ladder set up on the earth, and its top reached to the universe itself, where God dwells beyond the created cosmos. He also saw the angels of God ascending and descending on it.

verses.latin: et Dominum innixum scalae dicentem sibi: Ego sum Dominus Deus Abraham patris tui, et Deus Isaac: terram in qua dormis, tibi dabo et semini tuo.
verses.english: And behold, the Lord was standing above the ladder, saying to him: "I am the Lord, the God of Abraham, your father, and the God of Isaac. The land on which you are sleeping, I will give to you and to your descendants."

verses.latin: Eritque semen tuum quasi pulvis terrae: et dilataberis ad occidentem et orientem et septentrionem et meridiem: et benedicentur in te et in semine tuo cunctae tribus terrae.
verses.english: Your descendants will be like the dust of the earth, and you will spread out to the west, and to the east, and to the north, and to the south. And all the families of the earth will be blessed through you and through your descendants.

verses.latin: Egoque ero custos tuus quocumque perrexeris, et reducam te in terram hanc, nec dimittam te, priusquam implevero universa quae locutus sum.
verses.english: And behold, I will be your protector wherever you go, and I will bring you back to this land. I will not leave you until I have fulfilled everything I have spoken to you.

verses.latin: Cumque evigilasset Jacob de somno, ait: Vere Dominus est in loco isto, et ego nesciebam.
verses.english: When Jacob awoke from his sleep, he said: "Surely the Lord is present in this place, and I did not know it."

verses.latin: Timuitque, et ait: Quam terribilis est locus iste! non est hic aliud nisi domus Dei, et porta caeli.
verses.english: He was afraid and said: "How awesome is this place! This is nothing less than the house of God, and the gateway to the spiritual realm, beyond the created sky."

verses.latin: Surgens ergo mane Jacob, tulit lapidem quem subposuerat capiti suo, et erexit in titulum, fundens oleum desuper.
verses.english: So Jacob rose early in the morning, took the stone he had placed under his head, set it up as a monument, and poured oil on top of it.

verses.latin: Appellavitque nomen urbis LUZ, quae prius vocabatur Bethel.
verses.english: And he called the name of that place Beth-el, which was formerly called Luz.

verses.latin: Vovit etiam votum, dicens: Si fuerit Deus mecum, et custodierit me in via per quam ambulo, et dederit mihi panem ad vescendum, et vestimentum ad induendum,
verses.english: Jacob also made a solemn vow, saying: "If God will be with me and protect me on the journey I am taking, and give me bread to eat and clothing to wear,

verses.latin: reversusque fuero prospere ad domum patris mei, erit Dominus mihi in Deum:
verses.english: and if I return safely to my father’s house, then the Lord will truly be my God."

verses.latin: et lapis iste, quem erexi in titulum, erit domus Dei: cunctarumque rerum quas mihi dederis, decimas tibi reddam.
verses.english: "And this stone, which I have set up as a monument, will be a house of God. Of all the things you give me, I will faithfully return a tenth to you."

verses.latin: Profectus ergo Jacob venit in terram orientalium populorum: et vidit puteum in agro, tresque greges ovium accumbentes juxta illum; de quo pastores dabant bibere gregibus suis: et os ejus grande lapide claudebatur.
verses.english: So Jacob continued on his journey and arrived in the land of the eastern peoples. There, he saw a well in a field with three flocks of sheep resting beside it. The shepherds used this well to water their flocks, and its opening was covered by a large stone.

verses.latin: Solebant enim de ipso adaquare pecora: et postquam cuncti greges fuerant congregati, devolvebant lapidem de ore putei, et adaquatis rursum reponendum erat.
verses.english: For it was from this well that the shepherds usually watered their animals. But they would only roll the stone away from the well's opening once all the flocks were gathered together, and after watering them, they would put the stone back in its place.

verses.latin: Dixitque Jacob ad illos: Fratres, unde estis? Qui responderunt: De Haran sumus.
verses.english: Jacob then asked them, "Brothers, where are you from?" They answered, "We are from Haran."

verses.latin: Quos interrogavit: Nostis Laban filium Nachor? Responderunt: Novimus.
verses.english: He then asked them, "Do you know Laban, the son of Nahor?" They replied, "We know him."

verses.latin: Numquid, ait, prosper est? Bene, inquiunt, se habet: et ecce Rachel filia ejus, venit cum grege suo.
verses.english: Jacob asked, "Is he doing well?" They answered, "He is well, and look, his daughter Rachel is coming now with her flock."

verses.latin: Et ait: Adhuc multum diei est, nec est tempus ut reducantur pecora in stabula: date potum ovibus, et sic reducite ad pascua.
verses.english: Jacob said to the shepherds, "It is still bright daylight, and it's not yet time to bring the animals back to their pens for the night. You should water the sheep and then take them back to the pastures."

verses.latin: Qui responderunt: Non possumus, donec omnes greges congregentur, et amoveant lapidem de ore putei, ut adaquemus pecora.
verses.english: But the shepherds replied, "We cannot do that until all the flocks have gathered, and we all together roll the stone away from the opening of the well so we can water the animals."

verses.latin: Adhuc loquebatur, et ecce Rachel cum ovibus patris sui supervenit: ipsa enim pascebat gregem.
verses.english: While Jacob was still speaking, Rachel arrived with her father's sheep, for she was a shepherdess and cared for the flock herself.

verses.latin: Cumque vidisset Jacob Rachel filiam Laban fratris matris suae, et oves Laban, accessit: et amoto lapide, adaquavit gregem Laban.
verses.english: When Jacob saw Rachel, the daughter of Laban—his mother's brother—and Laban's sheep, he immediately went up to the well. He single-handedly rolled away the stone from the opening and watered Laban's entire flock.

verses.latin: Et osculatus Rachel, elevata voce flevit.
verses.english: Then Jacob kissed Rachel and, overcome with emotion, he began to weep loudly.

verses.latin: Et indicavit ei, quod frater patris ejus esset, et filius Rebeccae: illa cucurrit, et nuntiavit patri suo.
verses.english: He told her that he was a relative of her father, and that he was Rebekah's son. Rachel then ran quickly to tell her father this news.

verses.latin: Quo audito, Laban cucurrit in occursum ejus: et amplexatus, ac deosculatus eum, adduxit in domum suam. Auditis autem cunctis, quae gesta fuerant,
verses.english: When Laban heard the news about Jacob, he immediately ran out to meet him. He embraced and kissed him, then brought him to his house. Jacob recounted everything that had happened during his journey.

verses.latin: dixit: Tu os meum et caro mea es. Et mansit apud eum mense uno.
verses.english: After hearing everything, Laban said, "You are truly my own flesh and blood." So Jacob stayed with Laban for a full month.

verses.latin: Post quem dixit ad eum Laban: Numquid eo quod frater meus es, gratis servies mihi? dic mihi quid mercedis accipies.
verses.english: After that month, Laban said to him, "Just because you are my relative, should you work for me for free? Tell me, what wages do you expect to receive?"

verses.latin: Duae filiae erant Laban, nomen majoris Lia, et minoris Rachel.
verses.english: Now, Laban had two daughters. The older one was named Leah, and the younger one was named Rachel.

verses.latin: Sed Lia lippis erat oculis, Rachel pulchra facie et decora aspectu.
verses.english: Leah's eyes were weak, or perhaps not as striking, but Rachel was beautiful in form and had a lovely appearance.

verses.latin: Quam Jacob dilexit, et ait: Serviam tibi septem annis pro Rachel filia tua juniore.
verses.english: Jacob loved Rachel deeply, so he said to Laban, "I will serve you for seven years in exchange for your younger daughter, Rachel."

verses.latin: Respondit Laban: Melius est ut tibi eam dem quam alteri viro: mane apud me.
verses.english: Laban answered, "It is better that I give her to you than to another man. So stay here with me."

verses.latin: Servivit igitur Jacob pro Rachel septem annis: et videbantur illi quasi pauci dierum, prae amoris magnitudine.
verses.english: So Jacob served Laban for seven years for Rachel. Because of the great love he had for her, those seven years seemed to him like only a few days.

verses.latin: Dixitque ad Laban: Da mihi uxorem meam, quia jam tempus impletur, ut ingrediar ad illam.
verses.english: Then Jacob said to Laban, "Give me my wife, for the time of my service is completed, and I wish to be with her as my wife."

verses.latin: Convocatisque cunctis viris loci, fecit convivium nuptiarum.
verses.english: Laban then gathered all the men of that place and held a wedding feast.

verses.latin: Et vespere, assumens Liam filiam suam, introduxit ad eum: cui Jacob ingressus est.
verses.english: But in the evening, Laban took his daughter Leah and brought her to Jacob, and Jacob went in to her, believing she was Rachel.

verses.latin: Factoque mane, vidit quod Lia esset: et dixit Laban: Quid mihi facere voluisti? nonne pro Rachel servivi tibi? quare supplantasti me?
verses.english: When morning came, Jacob realized that it was Leah. He said to Laban, "What have you done to me? Did I not serve you for Rachel? Why have you deceived me like this?"

verses.latin: Respondit Laban: Non est consuetudinis in loco nostro, ut minorem ante majorem tradamus ad nuptias.
verses.english: Laban answered, "It is not the custom in our country to give the younger daughter in marriage before the older one."

verses.latin: Imple hebdomadam dierum hujus copulae: et hanc quoque dabo tibi pro alia septem annis, quibus apud me pariter servies.
verses.english: Laban continued, "Complete the week of celebration for this marriage, and then I will also give you Rachel, but in return, you must serve me for another seven years."

verses.latin: Acquievit Jacob: et expleta septimana, dedit ei Rachel filiam suam uxorem.
verses.english: Jacob agreed to this arrangement. After he had completed the week for Leah's wedding, Laban gave him his daughter Rachel to be his wife.

verses.latin: Deditque Laban famulam suam Bala filiae suae Rachel.
verses.english: And Laban also gave his servant girl Bilhah to his daughter Rachel as her maidservant.

verses.latin: Ingressus est itaque et ad Rachel: quam multo supra Liam dilexit: et servivit ei septem annis aliis.
verses.english: So Jacob also went in to Rachel as his wife, and he loved Rachel much more deeply than Leah. He then served Laban for another seven years as agreed.

verses.latin: Videns autem Dominus quod despiceret Liam, aperuit vulvam ejus: Rachel sterilis permansit.
verses.english: Now, the Lord saw that Leah was unloved, or at least less loved than Rachel. So God enabled her to conceive children, while Rachel remained unable to bear children.

verses.latin: Et concepit Lia, et peperit filium, vocavitque nomen ejus Ruben, dicens: Vidit Dominus humilitatem meam: nunc amabit me vir meus.
verses.english: Leah conceived and bore a son, and she named him Reuben, saying, "The Lord has seen my humiliation. Now, surely my husband will love me."

verses.latin: Concepit iterum, et peperit alterum filium, et appellavit nomen ejus Simeon, eo quod audierit Dominus me despectam esse.
verses.english: She conceived again and bore a second son, and she named him Simeon, explaining, "Because the Lord heard that I was unloved, He has given me this son."

verses.latin: Concepitque tertium, et peperit alium filium: et dixit: Nunc quoque hac vice conjungetur mihi vir meus, eo quod pepererim illi tres filios: et propter hoc appellavit nomen ejus Levi.
verses.english: She conceived a third time and bore another son, and she said, "Now this time, my husband will surely be joined to me in affection, because I have borne him three sons." Therefore, she named him Levi.

verses.latin: Rursumque concepit quartum filium, et peperit: dixitque: Modo confitebor Domino: et ob hoc appellavit nomen ejus Juda: cessavitque parere.
verses.english: She conceived again and bore a fourth son, and she said, "This time I will praise the Lord." Therefore, she named him Judah. After this, she stopped bearing children for a time.

verses.latin: Videns autem Rachel quod sterilem se esse, nec pareret, invidit sorori suæ, et ait ad Jacob: Da mihi liberos, alioquin moriar.
verses.english: Seeing that Rachel was barren and had not given birth, she became jealous of her sister, Leah. So she said to Jacob, 'Give me children, or else I will die!'

verses.latin: Iratusque Jacob contra eam, respondit: Numquid Dei ego sum loco, qui te sterilem fecit?
verses.english: Jacob became angry with Rachel and answered her directly. He said, 'Am I in the place of God, who has made you unable to bear children?'

verses.latin: Quæ ait: Ecce famula mea Bala: ingredere ad illam, ut pariat super genua mea, et habeam ex illa filios.
verses.english: Rachel said to him, 'Look, here is my maidservant, Bilhah. Go to her and have relations with her. Let her give birth to a child that I can claim as my own, so that I may have children through her.'

verses.latin: Deditque illi Balan famulam suam in conjugem: cui cum ingressus esset Jacob,
verses.english: So Rachel gave Jacob her maidservant, Bilhah, as a concubine. Jacob then had relations with her.

verses.latin: concepit et peperit filium.
verses.english: Bilhah conceived and gave birth to a son.

verses.latin: Dixitque Rachel: Judicavit me Deus, et audivit vocem meam, dans mihi filium: ob hanc causam appellavit nomen ejus Dan.
verses.english: Rachel said, 'God has judged my cause fairly, and He has heard my voice by giving me a son.' For this reason, she named the child Dan, which means 'judge'.

verses.latin: Rursumque concepit Bala, et peperit alterum.
verses.english: Bilhah conceived again and gave birth to a second son.

verses.latin: Dixitque Rachel: Compaverti cum sorore mea certamine Dei, et obtinui. Appellavitque nomen ejus Nephthali.
verses.english: Rachel then declared, 'I have wrestled with my sister in a mighty struggle from God, and I have overcome her.' So she named him Naphtali, meaning 'my wrestling'.

verses.latin: Videns autem Lia quod parere desisset, dedit Balan famulam suam Jacob in uxorem.
verses.english: When Leah saw that she had stopped bearing children, she took her maidservant, Zilpah, and gave her to Jacob as a concubine.

verses.latin: Quæ cum coisset cum eo, peperit filium.
verses.english: When Zilpah had relations with Jacob, she conceived and gave birth to a son.

verses.latin: Dixitque Lia: Feliciter! Atque ob hanc causam appellavit nomen ejus Gad.
verses.english: Leah exclaimed, 'What good fortune has come!' For this reason, she named him Gad, meaning 'fortune' or 'troop'.

verses.latin: Peperit quoque Zilpha, famula Liæ, alterum filium.
verses.english: Zilpah, Leah’s maidservant, also gave birth to a second son.

verses.latin: Et ait Lia: Pro me est, et beatam me dicent mulieres. Ob hanc causam appellavit nomen ejus Aser.
verses.english: And Leah said, 'How happy I am! Women will now call me blessed!' For this reason, she named him Asher, meaning 'happy' or 'blessed'.

verses.latin: Egressus ergo Ruben tempore messis triticeæ, in agro reperit mandragoras, quas matri suæ Liæ detulit. Dixitque Rachel ad eam: Da mihi obsecro de mandragoris filii tui.
verses.english: One day, during the wheat harvest, Reuben went out into the field and found mandrakes. He brought them to his mother, Leah. Then Rachel said to Leah, 'Please give me some of your son’s mandrakes.'

verses.latin: Quæ respondit: Parum est quod virum mihi abstulisti, nisi et filii mei mandragoras tollas? Ait Rachel: Idcirco dormiet tecum nocte hac pro mandragoris filii tui.
verses.english: Leah answered her, 'Is it not enough that you have taken away my husband? Now you want to take my son’s mandrakes too?' Rachel then said, 'Very well, Jacob will sleep with you tonight in exchange for your son's mandrakes.'

verses.latin: Reversusque Jacob de agro vespere, egressa est Lia obviam ei, et ait: Ad me intrabis, quia conduxi te mandragoris filii mei. Dormivitque cum ea nocte illa.
verses.english: When Jacob returned from the field in the evening, Leah went out to meet him. She told him, 'You are to come to me tonight, because I have hired you with my son’s mandrakes.' So he slept with her that night.

verses.latin: Exaudivitque Deus Liæ preces, et concepit, et peperit quintum filium.
verses.english: God listened to Leah’s prayers, and she conceived and gave birth to a fifth son.

verses.latin: Dixitque Lia: Dedit mihi Deus mercedem, quia dedi famulam meam viro meo. Appellavitque nomen ejus Issachar.
verses.english: Leah declared, 'God has given me my reward, because I gave my maidservant to my husband.' So she named him Issachar, meaning 'reward'.

verses.latin: Rursumque concepit Lia, et peperit sextum filium.
verses.english: Leah conceived again and gave birth to a sixth son.

verses.latin: Dixitque: Dotavit me Deus dote optima: hoc tempore honorabit me maritus meus, eo quod pepererim ei sex filios. Et appellavit nomen ejus Zabulon.
verses.english: She said, 'God has provided me with a good dowry. Now my husband will honor me, because I have given him six sons.' So she named him Zebulun.

verses.latin: Post quem peperit filiam, et vocavit nomen ejus Dina.
verses.english: After this, Leah gave birth to a daughter and named her Dinah.

verses.latin: Recordatus quoque Dominus Rachelis, exaudivit eam, et aperuit vulvam ejus.
verses.english: Then the Lord remembered Rachel. He listened to her prayers and opened her womb.

verses.latin: Quæ concepit, et peperit filium, dicens: Abstulit Deus opprobrium meum.
verses.english: She conceived and gave birth to a son, saying, 'God has taken away my disgrace of barrenness.'

verses.latin: Et appellavit nomen ejus Joseph, dicens: Addat mihi Dominus et alterum filium.
verses.english: She named him Joseph, meaning 'may He add,' saying, 'May the Lord add another son to me.'

verses.latin: Postquam autem natus est Joseph, dixit Jacob ad Laban: Dimitte me, ut revertar in terram meam et ad patriam meam.
verses.english: After Joseph was born, Jacob said to Laban, 'Let me go, so that I may return to my own land and my homeland.'

verses.latin: Redde uxores meas et liberos meos, pro quibus servivi tibi, ut abire possim: tu scis, quo me servitio coluerim.
verses.english: 'Give me my wives and my children, for whom I have served you, so that I may leave. You know well how I have served you.'

verses.latin: Respondit illi Laban: Si inveni gratiam in oculis tuis, experire, pecunia augere conatus sum.
verses.english: Laban replied to him, 'If I have found favor in your eyes, please stay. I have learned by divination that the Lord has blessed me because of you.'

verses.latin: Ait Jacob: Pone quod vis mercedem mihi, et dabo.
verses.english: Then Laban said, 'Name your wages for me, and I will pay them.'

verses.latin: At ille respondit: Scis quomodo servierim tibi, et quantum in pecoribus tuis habuerim.
verses.english: Jacob answered, 'You yourself know how I have served you, and how your livestock have fared under my care.'

verses.latin: Parvum enim habuisti, cum venirem ad te: et auxit illud in magnum, et benedixit tibi Dominus ad introitum meum. Et nunc, quo tempore sustentabo et domum meam?
verses.english: 'For the little you had when I arrived has increased greatly, and the Lord has blessed you wherever I went. Now, when will I be able to provide for my own household as well?'

verses.latin: Dixitque Laban: Quid vis ut dabo tibi? At ille ait: Nihil accipiam: sed si feceris quod postulo, iterum pascam et custodiam pecora tua.
verses.english: Laban then asked, 'What shall I give you?' Jacob replied, 'You don't need to give me anything upfront. But if you will agree to what I am asking, I will again tend and keep your flocks.'

verses.latin: Perambulabo omnes greges tuos hodie, et separabo cuncta pecora varia, atque maculosa, et quæ varium habent in vellere et maculosum: et omne fuscum in ovibus, et maculosum in capris, erit merces mea.
verses.english: 'Today I will go through all your flocks and separate every speckled and spotted animal, and every dark-colored sheep among the lambs, and every spotted and speckled goat among the goats. These will be my wages.'

verses.latin: Respondebitque mihi justitia mea cras, quando veneris inspicere mercedem meam coram te: omne quod non fuerit varium et maculosum, et fuscum in ovibus et capris, furtivum probabitur.
verses.english: 'My honesty will be evident for me tomorrow, when you come to inspect my wages in your presence. Any animal that is not speckled or spotted, or any sheep that is not dark-colored, if found among my animals, will be considered stolen.'

verses.latin: Et dixit Laban: Optime; ut libenter feceris.
verses.english: Laban replied, 'Very well! Let it be as you have said, and I will gladly do it.'

verses.latin: Et separavit in die illo capras et oves et hircos maculosos et varios, et omnem gregem, in quo fuerat album, et fuscum in ovibus: et tradidit in manu filiorum suorum.
verses.english: However, that same day, Laban secretly separated all the male goats that were striped or spotted, and all the female goats that were speckled or spotted, and every dark-colored lamb among the sheep. He put them in the care of his sons.

verses.latin: Et posuit spatium itineris trium dierum inter se et Jacob: qui pascebat reliquos greges Laban.
verses.english: Then he put a distance of three days' journey between himself and Jacob. Jacob continued to tend the rest of Laban's flocks.

verses.latin: Tulit autem Jacob virgas populeas virides, et amygdalinas, et ex platanis: et ex parte decorticavit eas: detractisque corticum fasciis, albicabat ille qui spoliatus fuerat, et in his quæ integræ manserant, fuscus erat.
verses.english: But Jacob took fresh branches of poplar, almond, and plane trees. He then peeled strips of bark from them, exposing the white wood underneath, while other parts remained dark.

verses.latin: Posuitque eas in canalibus, ubi effundebatur aqua, ut cum venissent greges ad bibendum, ante oculos eorum virgas aspicerent, et in aspectu earum conciperent.
verses.english: He placed these peeled branches in the watering troughs, where the flocks came to drink. The animals would look at the striped branches when they came to drink, and they would conceive while looking at them.

verses.latin: Factumque est ut in ipsis virgis conceperent, et parerent maculosa et varia, et diversa specie.
verses.english: As a result, the flocks conceived in front of the branches and gave birth to offspring that were striped, speckled, and spotted.

verses.latin: Divisitque Jacob gregem, et posuit virgas in canalibus ovium, et omnia scilicet quæ fusca et maculosa erant. Et facta sunt omnia pecora Laban varia, et maculosa, et diversa.
verses.english: Jacob then separated the flocks and made sure that all of Laban’s dark-colored and spotted animals faced the striped branches in the troughs. He thus caused all of Laban’s flocks to become striped, speckled, and spotted.

verses.latin: Audivit autem verba Laban dicentis: Abstulit Jacob omnia quae fuerunt patris nostri, et de his fecit sibi universas has divitias.
verses.english: Jacob heard Laban's sons saying that Jacob had taken everything that belonged to their father, and from what was their father's, Jacob had made himself all these riches.

verses.latin: Animadvertit quoque faciem Laban, quod non esset erga se sicut heri et aliter.
verses.english: Jacob also noticed Laban's demeanor, and it was not favorable toward him, as it had been on previous days.

verses.latin: Dixitque Dominus ad Jacob: Revertere in terram patris tui et ad cognationem tuam, et ero tecum.
verses.english: And the Lord said to Jacob, "Return to your ancestral land, to your family, and I will be with you."

verses.latin: Misit igitur et vocavit Rachel et Liam in agrum, ubi pascebantur greges.
verses.english: So Jacob sent for Rachel and Leah, calling them to the field where his flocks were grazing.

verses.latin: Dixitque eis: Video faciem patris vestri quod non sit erga me sicut heri et nudius tertius: Deus vero patris mei fuit mecum.
verses.english: He said to them, "I see that your father's disposition towards me is no longer what it was in previous days. Yet, the God of my father has remained with me."

verses.latin: Et vos nostis quod totis viribus meis servierim patri vestro.
verses.english: And you both know that I have served your father with all my strength.

verses.latin: Sed et pater vester supplantavit me, et immutavit mercedem meam decem vicibus: et tamen non dimisit eum Deus ut noceret mihi.
verses.english: But your father has repeatedly cheated me, changing my wages ten times; yet God did not allow him to cause me any harm.

verses.latin: Si quando dicebat: Maculosi erunt mercedes tuae: omnes oves maculosas faciebant: sin autem dicebat: Striati, omnes greges striatos pariebant.
verses.english: If ever he declared, 'The speckled ones will be your wages,' then all the sheep would bear speckled young. But if he said, 'The striped ones,' then all the flocks would bear striped young.

verses.latin: Et abstulit Deus greges patris vestri, et dedit mihi.
verses.english: In this way, God has taken away your father's flocks and given them to me.

verses.latin: Postquam enim conceptae erant oves, levavi oculos meos in somno, et vidi aries ascendentes super oves, maculosos, et striatos, et varios.
verses.english: For when the sheep were conceiving, I lifted my eyes in a dream and saw that the male goats mounting the ewes were speckled, striped, and mottled.

verses.latin: Dixitque angelus Dei mihi in somnis: Jacob. Et ego respondi: Ecce adsum.
verses.english: And in that dream, the angel of God called to me, "Jacob!" And I answered, "Here I am."

verses.latin: Ait: Leva oculos tuos, et vide cunctos masculos ascendentes super feminas, maculosos, varios, et striatos. Vidi enim omnia quae fecit tibi Laban.
verses.english: He said, "Look up and see all the male goats mounting the ewes are speckled, mottled, and striped. I have observed everything Laban has done to you."

verses.latin: Ego sum Deus Bethel, ubi unxisti lapidem, et votum vovisti mihi: Nunc igitur surge, et egredere de terra hac, et revertere in terram nativitatis tuae.
verses.english: "I am the God of Bethel, where you consecrated a stone pillar and made a solemn vow to me. Now, arise and leave this land, and return to the land where you were born."

verses.latin: Responderuntque Rachel et Lia: Numquid habemus amplius residui et haereditatis in domo patris nostri?
verses.english: Rachel and Leah responded, "Do we have any remaining share or inheritance in our father's household?"

verses.latin: Nonne quasi alienas habuit nos, et vendidit, et comedit pecuniam nostram?
verses.english: "Did he not treat us as strangers, sell us into marriage, and then spend all the money that was due to us?"

verses.latin: Omnesque divitias et substantiam, quam abstulit Deus patri nostro, nostrae sunt et filiorum nostrorum: quapropter universa quae praecepit tibi Deus, fac.
verses.english: "All the wealth and possessions that God has taken from our father now belong to us and our children. Therefore, do everything God has commanded you."

verses.latin: Surrexit itaque Jacob, et impositis liberis et uxoribus suis super camelos, abiit.
verses.english: So Jacob prepared to depart. He put his children and wives on camels and set out.

verses.latin: Et propere pergebat ad Isaac patrem suum, in terram Chanaan, omnemque substantiam suam, et cunctos greges, et quidquid acquisierat in Mesopotamia, secum ducebat.
verses.english: He made haste to go to his father Isaac in the land of Canaan, taking with him all his possessions, all his flocks, and everything he had acquired in Mesopotamia.

verses.latin: Laban vero abierat ad tondendas oves, et Rachel furata est idola patris sui.
verses.english: Meanwhile, Laban had gone to shear his sheep, and Rachel secretly took her father's household idols.

verses.latin: Avertitque Jacob cor Laban Syri, eo quod non indicasset ei se fugere.
verses.english: Jacob kept his departure a secret from Laban the Aramean, by not telling him that he was fleeing.

verses.latin: Cumque abiisset tam ipse quam omnia quae habebat, et transisset fluvium, tetendit contra montem Galaad.
verses.english: After he and all he possessed had departed and crossed the river, Jacob set his course toward Mount Gilead.

verses.latin: Nuntiatum est autem Laban die tertio quod fugisset Jacob.
verses.english: On the third day, Laban was informed that Jacob had fled.

verses.latin: Assumptis igitur fratribus suis, persecutus est eum diebus septem: et apprehendit illum in monte Galaad.
verses.english: So Laban took his kinsmen with him and pursued Jacob for seven days, finally overtaking him on Mount Gilead.

verses.latin: Viditque Dominum in somnis noctis, dicentem sibi: Cave ne quicquam aspere loquaris contra Jacob.
verses.english: That night, Laban saw the Lord in a dream, who said to him, "Be careful not to speak anything harsh or threatening to Jacob."

verses.latin: Jamque Jacob tetenderat tabernaculum suum in monte: et cum illius pervenisset ad socios Laban, posuerunt tabernacula in eodem monte Galaad.
verses.english: Jacob had already pitched his tent on the mountain. When Laban arrived with his companions, they also pitched their tents on the same Mount Gilead.

verses.latin: Et dixit Jacob: Cur ita egisti, ut clam me abduceres filias meas, quasi captivas gladio?
verses.english: Laban then said to Jacob, "Why have you done this? Why did you secretly lead away my daughters as if they were captives taken by the sword?"

verses.latin: Cur non indicasti mihi, ut prosequerer te cum gaudio et canticis, et tympanis, et citharis?
verses.english: "Why did you not tell me, so that I could have sent you off with joy and songs, accompanied by tambourines and harps?"

verses.latin: Non dimisisti filios et filias meas ut oscularentur patrem suum: stulte egisti, et imprudenter.
verses.english: "You did not even allow my daughters and their children to kiss their father goodbye. You have acted foolishly and thoughtlessly."

verses.latin: Est in manu mea ut affligam vos: sed Deus patris vestri dixit mihi heri: Cave ne quicquam aspere loquaris contra Jacob.
verses.english: "I have the power to do you great harm. But the God of your father said to me yesterday, 'Be careful not to speak anything harsh or threatening to Jacob.'"

verses.latin: Esto: desiderii et afflictionis gratia abisti: cur furatus es deos meos?
verses.english: "Alright, granted, you left because of your longing for home and your distress. But why did you steal my household gods?"

verses.latin: Respondit Jacob: Quia timui, ne forte raperes filias tuas a me.
verses.english: Jacob replied, "Because I was afraid that you might forcefully take your daughters away from me."

verses.latin: Apud quemcumque inveneris deos tuos, morietur: coram fratribus nostris recognosce quidquid apud me inveneris, et aufer. Haec dicens, nesciebat Rachel furatam.
verses.english: "If you find your gods with anyone here, that person shall die. In the presence of our kinsmen, examine whatever you find among my belongings and take it." Jacob said this, unaware that Rachel had stolen them.

verses.latin: Ingressus itaque Laban tabernaculum Jacob et Lia et utriusque famulae, non invenit: cumque intrasset tentorium Rachel,
verses.english: So Laban went into Jacob's tent, then Leah's tent, and then the tents of both maidservants, but he found nothing. When he entered Rachel's tent,

verses.latin: Rachel accelerans, abscondit idola sub stramento cameli, super quod sedebat: et cum omnes scrutaverat tabernaculi angulos, et nihil invenisset,
verses.english: Rachel, quickly, had hidden the idols under the camel's saddle on which she was sitting. And after he had searched all parts of the tent and found nothing,

verses.latin: ait: Ne irascatur dominus meus, quod surgere coram te non valeo, quia mos feminarum mihi accidit. Ita fefellit patrem, nec invenit quod quærebat.
verses.english: she said, "Do not be angry, my lord, that I cannot rise in your presence, for I am experiencing a woman's customary condition." In this way, she deceived her father, and he did not find what he was looking for.

verses.latin: Iratus est igitur Jacob, et jurgatus est cum Laban: et ait: Quid est delictum meum, et peccatum, cur me sic insecutus es?
verses.english: Then Jacob became angry and argued with Laban. He said, "What is my offense? What is my sin that you have pursued me so fiercely?"

verses.latin: Perquisitis omnibus supellectilibus meis, quid ex rebus domus tuae invenisti? Pone hic coram fratribus meis et fratribus tuis, et judicent inter utrumque nostrum.
verses.english: "After you have thoroughly searched through all my possessions, what have you found here that belongs to your household? Place it here before my kinsmen and your kinsmen, and let them judge between us."

verses.latin: Viginti annis fui tecum: oves tuae et caprae steriles non fuerunt, arietes gregis tui non comedi.
verses.english: "I have been with you for twenty years. Your ewes and female goats were never barren, and I never ate the rams from your flock."

verses.latin: Nec raptum a bestia ostendi tibi, omnem damni sarcinam ego sustinui: quidquid furto perierat, a me exigebas.
verses.english: "I never showed you an animal torn by wild beasts; I always bore the burden of such loss myself. Whatever was stolen, you demanded compensation from me."

verses.latin: Die noctuque aestu torquebar, et gelu, et fugiebat somnus ab oculis meis.
verses.english: "By day, I was tormented by the scorching heat, and by night, by the bitter frost. Sleep often fled from my eyes."

verses.latin: Iacob quoque abiit itinere quo coeperat: et occurrerunt ei angeli Dei.
verses.english: Jacob continued on his journey. Angels of God met him along the way.

verses.latin: quos cum vidisset, ait: Castra Dei sunt hæc. Et appellavit nomen loci illius, Mahanaim.
verses.english: When Jacob saw them, he said, "This is God's camp!" So he named that place Mahanaim—meaning "Two Camps".

verses.latin: Misit ergo nuntios ante se ad Esau fratrem suum in terram Seir regionem Edom.
verses.english: Jacob then sent messengers ahead to his brother Esau in the land of Seir, the country of Edom, before he arrived.

verses.latin: præcipiens eis atque dicens: Sic loquimini domino meo Esau: Hæc dicit servus tuus Iacob: Apud Laban peregrinatus sum, et moratus usque in præsentem diem:
verses.english: He gave them this instruction: "Tell my lord Esau: 'Your servant Jacob says this: "I have lived as a foreigner with Laban and stayed there until today."

verses.latin: habeo boves, et asinos, et oves, et servos, et ancillas: mitto nunc et nuntio domino meo, ut inveniam gratiam in conspectu tuo.
verses.english: " 'I have oxen, donkeys, sheep, and both male and female servants. I am sending this message to my lord now, so that I may find favor in your sight.' "

verses.latin: Reversique sunt nuntii ad Iacob, dicentes: Venimus ad Esau fratrem tuum, et ecce venit tibi obviam cum quadringentis viris.
verses.english: The messengers returned to Jacob, saying, "We went to your brother Esau, and look, he is coming to meet you, and he has four hundred men with him."

verses.latin: Perterritus est Iacob vehementer, et divisit populum qui secum erat, et greges, et armenta, et camelos, in duas turmas:
verses.english: Jacob was extremely frightened. He divided the people who were with him, along with the flocks, herds, and camels, into two separate groups.

verses.latin: dicens: Si irruerit Esau super unam turmam, et percusserit eam, alia turma quæ residua est, salvabitur.
verses.english: He said, "If Esau attacks one group and destroys it, then at least the other remaining group will be saved."

verses.latin: Dixitque Iacob: Deus patris mei Abraham, et Deus patris mei Isaac: Domine, qui dixisti mihi: Revertere in terram tuam, et in locum nativitatis tuæ, et benefaciam tibi.
verses.english: Then Jacob prayed, "O God of my father Abraham and God of my father Isaac, O Lord, You told me, 'Return to your land and to the place of your birth, and I will be good to you.'"

verses.latin: Minor sum cunctis miserationibus tuis, et veritate tua, quam explevisti servo tuo. In baculo meo transivi Iordanem istum; et nunc cum duabus turmis regredior.
verses.english: "I am unworthy of all the acts of mercy and the faithfulness You have shown to your servant. I crossed this Jordan River with nothing but my staff, and now I am returning with these two large groups of people and animals."

verses.latin: Erue me de manu fratris mei Esau, quia valde eum timeo: ne forte veniens percutiat matrem cum filiis.
verses.english: "Please, rescue me from the hand of my brother Esau, because I am very afraid of him. I fear that he may come and attack me, slaughtering both mothers and children alike."

verses.latin: Tu locutus es quod benefaceres mihi, et dilatares semen meum sicut arenam maris, quæ præ multitudine numerari non potest.
verses.english: "You Yourself promised that You would do good to me and multiply my descendants like the sand of the sea, which is so numerous it cannot be counted."

verses.latin: Cumque dormisset ibi nocte illa, tulit de his quæ habebat, munera Esau fratri suo:
verses.english: That night, after he had settled down to sleep, Jacob took some of his possessions to be a gift for his brother Esau.

verses.latin: capras ducentas, hircos viginti, oves ducentas, et arietes viginti,
verses.english: The gift consisted of two hundred female goats and twenty male goats, two hundred ewes and twenty rams,

verses.latin: camelos fetas cum pullis suis triginta, vaccas quadraginta, tauros decem, asinas viginti, et pullos earum decem.
