verses.english: thirty female camels and their young, forty cows and ten bulls, and twenty female donkeys with ten of their young.

verses.latin: Et misit per manus servorum suorum singulos seorsum greges, dixitque ad famulos suos: Antecedite me, et sit spatium inter grex et grex.
verses.english: He gave these animals to his servants, dividing them into separate groups. He then instructed his servants, "Go on ahead of me, and leave a clear space between each group of animals."

verses.latin: Et præcepit priori dicens: Si obviam tibi fuerit Esau frater meus, et interrogaverit te, cujus sis, et quo pergas, aut cujus sint ista quæ ante te agis:
verses.english: He commanded the first servant, saying, "If my brother Esau meets you and asks, 'Whose servant are you? Where are you going? And to whom do these animals belong that you are driving?'"

verses.latin: respondebis: Servi tui Iacob sunt; munera misit domino suo Esau: et ipse post nos venit.
verses.english: "You are to answer, 'They belong to your servant Jacob. They are a gift sent to my lord Esau, and Jacob himself is coming right behind us.'"

verses.latin: Similiter præcepit secundo, et tertio, et omnibus qui sequebantur greges, dicens: Eadem verba loquimini ad Esau cum inveneritis eum:
verses.english: He gave the same instructions to the second servant, and to the third, and to all those who followed with the animal groups, saying, "Speak these exact same words to Esau when you encounter him."

verses.latin: et addite: Ipse quoque servus vester Iacob post nos venit. Dixit enim: Placabo illum muneribus quæ præcedunt, et postea videbo faciem ejus; forsitan propitiabitur mihi.
verses.english: "And be sure to add, 'Your servant Jacob is also coming right behind us.' " Jacob thought to himself, "I will appease him with these gifts that are going ahead of me. After that, when I see his face directly, perhaps he will receive me kindly and be reconciled with me."

verses.latin: Præcedentibus ergo muneribus, ipse pernoctavit nocte illa in castris.
verses.english: So the gifts went ahead of him, and Jacob spent that night in the camp.

verses.latin: Et cum surrexisset nocte, tulit duas uxores suas, et totidem ancillas, et undecim filios cum ipsis, et transivit vadum Iaboc.
verses.english: That very night, Jacob got up, took his two wives, his two female servants, and his eleven children, and crossed the ford of the Jabbok River.

verses.latin: Sublatisque illis, cum traduxisset aquas, omnia quæ possederat, traduxit.
verses.english: After he had sent them across the river, he sent over all his possessions as well.

verses.latin: Remansitque Iacob solus: et ecce vir luctabatur cum eo usque mane.
verses.english: Jacob remained alone on the other side. Then, a man wrestled with him until dawn.

verses.latin: Viditque quoniam non poterat eum, tetigit nervum femoris ejus, et statim luxata est articulatio femoris Iacob, luctantis cum eo.
verses.english: When the man saw that he could not overpower Jacob, he touched Jacob’s hip socket, and immediately Jacob's hip was dislocated as they wrestled.

verses.latin: Dixitque: Dimitte me, jam enim ascendit aurora. Respondit: Non dimittam te, nisi benedixeris mihi.
verses.english: The man said, "Let me go, for the dawn is breaking." But Jacob replied, "I will not let you go unless you bless me."

verses.latin: Ait ergo: Quid vocaris nomine? Respondit: Iacob.
verses.english: The man then asked him, "What is your name?" He answered, "Jacob."

verses.latin: At ille: Non Iacob, inquit, ultra vocabitur nomen tuum, sed Israel: quoniam si contra Deum fortis fuisti, quanto magis contra homines prævalebis?
verses.english: The man said, "Your name will no longer be called Jacob, but Israel, because you have struggled with God and with men, and have overcome." This new name signifies "He struggles with God" or "God strives."

verses.latin: Interrogavit illum Iacob: Appella mihi, obsecro, nomen tuum. Respondit: Cur quæris nomen meum? Et benedixit ei in eodem loco.
verses.english: Jacob asked him, "Please tell me your name." But the man replied, "Why do you ask for my name?" And He blessed Jacob right there in that place.

verses.latin: Vocavitque Iacob nomen loci illius Phanuel, dicens: Vidi Deum facie ad faciem, et salva facta est anima mea.
verses.english: Jacob named that place Penuel—meaning "Face of God"—saying, "I have seen God face to face, and yet my life has been preserved."

verses.latin: Ortusque est ei sol, statim postquam transierat Phanuel. Ipse vero claudicabat super femore suo.
verses.english: The sun rose upon him just as he was passing Penuel, and he was limping because of his hip.

verses.latin: Quam ob causam non comedunt filii Israel, usque in præsentem diem, nervum qui emarcuit in femore Iacob: eo quod tetigerit nervum femoris ejus, et obstupuerit.
verses.english: For this reason, to this very day, the children of Israel do not eat the sinew that is on the hip socket—the one that had shrunk in Jacob's thigh—because the man had touched the sinew of Jacob's hip, and it had shrunken.

verses.latin: Elevatis autem Jacob oculis, vidit venientem Esau, et cum eo quadringentos viros.
verses.english: Jacob looked up, and there was Esau approaching. With Esau were four hundred men, which was cause for Jacob's immediate alarm.

verses.latin: Et divisit filios ad Lia et Rachel, et utriusque famulas:
verses.english: Jacob then divided his children among Leah and Rachel, and also among their two servant women, arranging them for protection.

verses.latin: Et posuit utrasque famulas et earum liberos in principio, Liam vero et filios ejus in secundo loco, Rachel autem et Joseph novissimos.
verses.english: He placed the two servant women and their children at the very front of the procession; Leah and her children were placed behind them; and Rachel and Joseph, his most beloved, were placed last, in the safest position.

verses.latin: Ipse vero praecedens adoravit pronus in terram septies, donec appropinquaret frater ejus.
verses.english: But Jacob himself went ahead of them, bowing himself to the ground seven times in extreme submission, doing so until his brother Esau came close to him.

verses.latin: Currens itaque Esau obviam fratri suo, complexus est eum: stringensque collum ejus et osculans, flevit.
verses.english: Then Esau ran to meet his brother. He embraced him, put his arms around his neck, and kissed him, and they both wept.

verses.latin: Et sublevatis oculis, vidit mulieres et parvulos, et ait: Quid sibi volunt isti? Respondit: Parvuli sunt quos donavit mihi Deus servo tuo.
verses.english: Esau looked up and saw the women and children. He asked Jacob, "Who are these with you?" Jacob replied, "These are the children that God has graciously given to your servant."

verses.latin: Et accesserunt famulae et parvuli earum, et incurvati sunt.
verses.english: Then the servant women and their children came forward, and they all bowed down to Esau.

verses.latin: Accessit quoque Lia cum liberis suis, et cum similiter adorassent, postremo Rachel et Joseph accesserunt, et adoraverunt.
verses.english: Next, Leah and her children came forward, and they likewise bowed down. Finally, Rachel and Joseph came forward and bowed down to Esau.

verses.latin: Dixitque Esau: Quid sibi volunt greges isti, et turmas quas obviam habui? Respondit: Ut inveniam gratiam coram domino meo.
verses.english: Esau then asked, "What do you mean by all these droves and herds that I met on the way?" Jacob replied, "I hope to find favor in your sight, my lord."

verses.latin: Cui Esau: Habe, inquit, quae tua sunt, frater, mihi prospera sufficiunt.
verses.english: Esau said to him, "I have enough, my brother. Keep what is yours. I am well-provided for."

verses.latin: Dixit Jacob: Obsecro, si inveni gratiam in oculis tuis, accipe munusculum de manibus meis: pariter enim faciem tuam vidi, quasi viderim vultum Dei, et propitius susceperis me.
verses.english: Jacob replied, "No, I beg you, if I have truly found favor in your eyes, then please accept this gift from my hand. For to see your face is like seeing the face of God, and you have received me graciously."

verses.latin: Accipe benedictionem, quam attuli tibi, et quam donavit mihi Deus, qui omnia præbuit mihi.
verses.english: Please accept the blessing, this gift that I have brought for you, because God has been gracious to me and has given me everything I need and more." So Jacob urged him, and Esau took the gift.

verses.latin: Cum multum eum Jacob compelleret, et ille susciperet.
verses.english: Jacob kept urging him, and Esau finally accepted it.

verses.latin: Dixitque: Profectus in itinere, veniam ad te in Seir.
verses.english: Esau then said, "Let's set out and go. I will go along with you to Seir."

verses.latin: Respondit Jacob: Nosti, domine, quod parvuli teneri sint, et oves ac boves foetae mecum. Si ultra modum properare voluero, una die morientur cuncti greges.
verses.english: Jacob replied, "My lord knows that the children are tender, and that the flocks and herds nursing their young are a burden to me. If I drive them too hard for even one day, all the animals will die."

verses.latin: Quod si vis, vade paululum ante servum tuum: ego autem paulatim sequar, prout videre potero, ut accommodent se parvuli, donec veniam ad te in Seir.
verses.english: So please, my lord, go on ahead of your servant. I will follow slowly, at the pace of the livestock and the children, until I come to you in Seir."

verses.latin: Dixit Esau: Oramus, ut de populo meo saltem socii sint itineris tui. Respondit: Necesse est, ut super his, atque omnibus me facias securum.
verses.english: Esau said, "Let me at least leave some of my people with you to help on the journey." But Jacob replied, "What need is there for that, my lord? I am content with your kindness and protection for all these things."

verses.latin: Reversus est ergo Esau die illo via sua in Seir.
verses.english: So Esau turned back that day and went his way toward Seir.

verses.latin: Et Jacob venit in Succoth: ubi ædificata domo, et tentoriis fabricatis, appellavit nomen loci illius Succoth, id est, Tabernacula.
verses.english: Meanwhile, Jacob journeyed to Succoth, where he built a house for himself and made temporary shelters for his livestock. Therefore, he called the place Succoth, which means 'Shelters' or 'Booths'.

verses.latin: Transivitque ad Salem urbem Sichem, quæ est in terra Chanaan, postquam reversus est de Mesopotamia Syriæ, et habitavit juxta oppidum:
verses.english: Jacob then traveled safely to the city of Shechem, which is in the land of Canaan, after returning from Paddan-aram in Syria. He camped near the city.

verses.latin: Et emit partem agri, in qua fixerat tabernacula sua, a filiis Hemor patris Sichem, centum agnis.
verses.english: There, he bought a plot of land where he had pitched his tents from the sons of Hamor, Shechem's father, for one hundred pieces of money, or 'qesitas' in the ancient currency.

verses.latin: Et erexit ibi altare, et vocavit nomen ejus Fortissimus Deus Israel.
verses.english: He erected an altar there and called it El-Elohe-Israel, which means 'God, the God of Israel the Most Powerful'.

verses.latin: Egressa est autem Dina filia Liae, quam genuerat Jacob, ut videret mulieres regionis illius.
verses.english: Dina, the daughter of Leah and Jacob, went out to visit the women of that land.

verses.latin: Quam cum vidisset Sichem filius Hemor Hevaei, princeps terrae illius, adamavit eam, et rapuit, dormivitque cum illa, vi opprimens.
verses.english: When Shechem saw her, he was the son of Hamor the Hivite, and ruler of that land. He desired her strongly, seized her, and then violently raped her.

verses.latin: Et adhaesit animus ejus Dina filiae Jacob, et adamavit puellam, ac blande est locutus.
verses.english: Afterward, his affections became fixed on Dina, Jacob’s daughter. He loved the girl and spoke to her with words meant to soothe her heart.

verses.latin: Igitur Sichem locutus est ad Hemor patrem suum, dicens: Cape mihi uxorem hanc puellam.
verses.english: So Shechem spoke to his father Hamor, saying, 'Get this girl for me as a wife.'

verses.latin: Cum audisset autem Jacob, quod violasset Dinam filiam suam, et filii ejus foris essent in pastu pecorum, tacuit donec venirent.
verses.english: Jacob, however, heard the news that his daughter Dina had been violently disgraced. His sons were out in the fields tending the sheep at the time. So he remained silent, waiting for them to come home.

verses.latin: Et egressus Hemor pater Sichem, venit ad Jacob, ut loqueretur cum eo.
verses.english: Then Hamor, Shechem's father, came out to Jacob to speak with him about the matter.

verses.latin: Ecce autem filii ejus veniebant de agro: auditoque opere, quod patratum erat, irati sunt valde: quia rem execrabilem fecerat in Israël, et scelus non ferendum.
verses.english: When Jacob’s sons returned from the field, they heard what had been done. They were deeply enraged by the despicable act committed against Dina and the family’s honor in Israel, which was an intolerable crime.

verses.latin: Locutus est ergo Hemor ad eos: Sichem filius meus adhæsit anima sua filiæ vestræ: date eam illi uxorem: et jungamus cognationem.
verses.english: Then Hamor spoke to them, saying, 'My son Shechem has set his heart on your daughter. Please, give her to him in marriage. Let us form a bond of kinship between our families.'

verses.latin: Filias vestras nobis date, et filias nostras vobis accipite: et habitate nobiscum.
verses.english: 'Give your daughters to us, and take our daughters for yourselves as wives. Then you can live among us.'

verses.latin: Terra in arbitrio vestro est, colite eam, et negotiamini, et possidete.
verses.english: 'The land is at your disposal. You may cultivate it, engage in trade, and acquire property within it.'

verses.latin: Dixit quoque Sichem patri et fratribus ejus: Inveniam gratiam coram vobis: et quodcumque petieritis, dabo.
verses.english: Shechem then said to Dina's father and brothers, 'Grant me this favor, please. Whatever you ask of me, I will give you.'

verses.latin: Augmentate dotem, et exigite munera: et libenter tribuam, quodcumque decreveritis: tantum date mihi puellam uxorem.
verses.english: 'Demand as great a bride-price and gifts as you wish. I will gladly provide whatever you determine, as long as you give me the girl to be my wife.'

verses.latin: Responderunt filii Jacob Sichem et Hemor patre ejus dolose, et locuti sunt, quia contaminaverat Dinam sororem suam:
verses.english: Jacob's sons answered Shechem and his father Hamor deceitfully, speaking out of anger and a desire for vengeance, because Shechem had defiled their sister Dina.

verses.latin: Non possumus hoc facere, nec dare sororem nostram homini incircumciso: quia opprobrium est apud nos.
verses.english: They told them, 'We cannot do this, nor can we give our sister to a man who is uncircumcised. That would be a disgrace to us.'

verses.latin: In hoc foedere jungetur amicitia inter nos et vos: si vultis similes esse nostri, et circumcidatur in vobis omne masculinum:
verses.english: 'We will only form an alliance and friendship with you on this condition: if you are willing to become like us, and every male among you is circumcised.'

verses.latin: tunc et accipiemus et dabimus invicem filias nostras: et habitabimus vobiscum, erimusque unus populus.
verses.english: 'Then we will both take your daughters as wives and give our daughters to you. We will live among you, and we will become one people.'

verses.latin: Si autem contempseritis viri circumcidi, non accipiemus filiam nostram, sed ablata recedemus.
verses.english: 'But if you men refuse to be circumcised, then we will take our daughter back and leave your land.'

verses.latin: Placuit sermo eorum Hemor et Sichem filio ejus.
verses.english: Their words seemed good to Hamor and to his son Shechem.

verses.latin: Nec distulit adolescens, sed statim fecit quod fuerat imperatum: amabat quippe puellam valde, et erat gloriosus in omni domo patris sui.
verses.english: The young man Shechem did not delay, but immediately did what had been commanded. He loved the girl very much, and he was the most respected and honored in all his father's house.

verses.latin: Igitur Hemor et Sichem filius ejus ingressi portam civitatis, locuti sunt ad populum:
verses.english: Then Hamor and his son Shechem went to the gate of their city and spoke to the people there.

verses.latin: Homines isti pacifici sunt nobiscum, et volunt in terra residere: agant negotium, et colant eam. Spatiosa et latissima est: nihil prohibet, si filias eorum uxores acceperimus, et nostras illis dederimus.
verses.english: 'These men are peaceful toward us and wish to settle in our land. Let them conduct business and cultivate the land; it is spacious and vast enough for everyone. There is no reason why we should not take their daughters as wives and give our daughters to them.'

verses.latin: Unum est, quo hæc amicitia et societas confirmari potest: si omnes masculi nostri circumcisi fuerint, sicut et illi ipsi circumcisi sunt.
verses.english: 'There is only one condition by which this friendship and alliance can be established: if all our males are circumcised, just as they themselves are circumcised.'

verses.latin: Substantia et pecora, et cuncta quæ possident, nostra erunt: tantum in hoc acquievimus: et cohabitabimus cum eis.
verses.english: 'Their wealth, their livestock, and all their possessions will become ours. We only agree to this condition, and then we will live together with them as one people.'

verses.latin: Acquieverunt omnibus, et circumcisi sunt universi masculi, quotquot ingrediebantur portam civitatis.
verses.english: All the men who came out of the city gate agreed to their proposal, and every male among them was circumcised.

verses.latin: Ecce autem tertia die, quando maxime dolor vulnerum æstuabat, arripientes duo filii Jacob, Simeon et Levi, fratres Dinæ, gladios suos, ingressi sunt urbem confidenter, interfectisque universis masculis,
verses.english: Now on the third day, when the pain from their wounds was most intense, two of Jacob’s sons, Simeon and Levi, Dina's full brothers, each took his sword. They entered the city boldly and killed all the males.

verses.latin: Hemor quoque et Sichem filium ejus interfecerunt, et tulerunt Dinam de domo Sichem, egressique sunt.
verses.english: They also killed Hamor and his son Shechem. Then they took Dina from Shechem's house and departed.

verses.latin: Alii filii Jacob irruerunt super interfectos, et depopulati sunt urbem in ultionem stupri.
verses.english: The other sons of Jacob rushed upon the slain and plundered the city as an act of vengeance for the rape of their sister.

verses.latin: Oves, et boves, et asinos, et quæcumque in civitate fuerunt et in agris, tulerunt.
verses.english: They took all the sheep, cattle, and donkeys, as well as everything that was in the city and in the fields.

verses.latin: Parvulos et uxores captivas ducentes, diripuerunt omnia.
verses.english: They carried away all the young children and the women as captives, and they plundered everything else.

verses.latin: Dixitque Jacob ad Simeon et Levi: Turbastis me, et odiosum fecistis me Chanæis et Pherezæis habitatoribus terræ hujus. Paucitas numeri mei est: illi congregati percutient me, et delebor ego et domus mea.
verses.english: Then Jacob said to Simeon and Levi, 'You have brought trouble upon me and made me odious to the Canaanites and the Perizzites, the inhabitants of this land. My numbers are few compared to theirs. If they gather together and attack me, both I and my entire household will be destroyed.'

verses.latin: Responderunt: Num scortum haberi debuit soror nostra?
verses.english: But they answered, 'Should our sister have been treated like a harlot?'

verses.latin: Dixit quoque Deus ad Jacob: Surge, et ascende Bethel, et habita ibi: facque altare Deo, qui apparuit tibi quando fugiebas Esau fratrem tuum.
verses.english: God also said to Jacob: 'Get up and go up to Bethel, and live there. Make an altar there to God, the One who appeared to you when you were fleeing from your brother Esau.'

verses.latin: Quibus et omni familiae suae: Abjicite, inquit, deos alienos qui in medio vestri sunt, et mundamini, mutateque vestimenta vestra.
verses.english: Jacob then spoke to his household and all his people, saying: 'Cast away the foreign gods that are among you, and cleanse yourselves, and change your garments to symbolize your purification.'

verses.latin: Et surgite, et ascendamus Bethel, ut faciamus ibi altare Deo, qui exaudivit me in die tribulationis meae, et fuit socius itineris mei.
verses.english: 'Then get up, and let us go up to Bethel, so we can make an altar there to God. He heard me on the day of my trouble and has been a companion on my journey.'

verses.latin: Dederunt ergo ei omnes deos alienos, quos habebant, et inaures, quae erant in auribus eorum: quos infodit Jacob subter terebinthum, juxta urbem Sichem.
verses.english: So they gave to Jacob all the foreign gods they had, and the earrings that were in their ears – items often associated with pagan practices or amulets. Jacob buried these beneath the terebinth tree near the city of Shechem.

verses.latin: Cumque profecti essent, terror Domini invasit omnes per circuitum civitates, et non sunt ausi persequi eos.
verses.english: When they had departed, the terror of the Lord gripped all the surrounding cities, and no one dared to pursue them.

verses.latin: Venit igitur Jacob Luza, quae est in terra Chanaan, cognomento Bethel: ipse, et omnis populus cum eo.
verses.english: So Jacob came to Luz, which is in the land of Canaan, and it was also known by the name Bethel. He and all his people were with him.

verses.latin: AEdificavitque ibi altare, et appellavit nomen loci illius, Dei Bethel: ibi enim apparuerat ei Deus, quando fugiebat fratrem suum.
verses.english: And he built an altar there, and he called the name of that place 'God of Bethel' – meaning that God truly dwelt there. For it was there that God had appeared to him when he was fleeing from his brother.

verses.latin: Eo tempore mortua est Debora nutrix Rebeccae, et sepulta est subter quercum Bethel: et appellatum est nomen loci illius, Quercus fletus.
verses.english: At that time, Deborah, Rebecca's nurse, died and was buried under an oak tree at Bethel. The name of that place was then called 'Oak of Weeping,' marking a place of great sorrow for Jacob's family.

verses.latin: Apparuit autem Deus Jacob rursum postquam reversus est de Mesopotamia Syriae, benedixitque ei.
verses.english: God appeared to Jacob again after he had returned from Mesopotamia of Syria, and He blessed him.

verses.latin: Dicens: Non vocaberis ultra Jacob, sed Israel erit nomen tuum. Et appellavit nomen ejus Israel.
verses.english: God said: 'Your name will no longer be called Jacob, but Israel will be your name.' And indeed, He called his name Israel.

verses.latin: Dixitque ei Deus: Ego Deus omnipotens: cresce et multiplicare: gentesque et turmas nationum ex te erunt, regesque de lumbis tuis egredientur.
verses.english: And God said to him: 'I am God Almighty. Be fruitful and multiply. Both nations and a company of nations shall come from you, and kings shall come forth from your body.'

verses.latin: Et terram, quam dedi Abraham et Isaac, dabo tibi, et semini tuo post te.
verses.english: 'And the land which I gave to Abraham and Isaac, I will give to you and to your descendants after you.'

verses.latin: Et recessit ab illo in loco in quo locutus est ei.
verses.english: Then God departed from him in the very place where He had spoken with him.

verses.latin: Erexit autem Jacob titulum lapideum in loco quo locutus ei fuerat Deus: libans super eum libamina, et fundens oleum.
verses.english: Jacob then set up a stone pillar in the place where God had spoken with him, pouring a drink offering over it and anointing it with oil to consecrate the spot.

verses.latin: Appellavitque nomen loci illius, Bethel.
verses.english: And he called the name of that very place, Bethel.

verses.latin: Profectique de Bethel, venerunt in terram Ephratha, in qua cum pareret Rachel, difficilius habuit in partu.
verses.english: Having journeyed from Bethel, they came to the land of Ephrath. While there, Rachel was giving birth, and she experienced a very difficult labor.

verses.latin: Post gravissimos dolores, dixit ei obstetrix: Noli timere, hoc quoque filius erit tibi.
verses.english: After severe pains, the midwife said to her: 'Do not fear, you will also have this son.'

verses.latin: Eminentique anima, et jam moriturae, appellavit nomen ejus Benoni, id est, Filius doloris mei: pater vero ejus vocavit eum Benjamin, id est, Filius dexterae.
verses.english: As her life was ebbing away, and she was already dying, she called his name Benoni, which means 'Son of my sorrow.' But his father called him Benjamin, meaning 'Son of the right hand,' to give him a name of blessing instead.

verses.latin: Mortua est ergo Rachel, et sepulta est in via Ephratha, hoc est Bethlehem.
verses.english: So Rachel died and was buried on the road to Ephrath, which is Bethlehem.

verses.latin: Erexit illi Jacob titulum super sepulcrum ejus: hic est titulus monumenti Rachel usque in praesentem diem.
verses.english: Jacob set up a pillar over her grave. This pillar marks Rachel's monument even to the present day.

verses.latin: Proficiscens inde Israel, tetendit tabernaculum suum ultra turrem Eder.
verses.english: Journeying from there, Israel (Jacob) pitched his tent beyond the Tower of Eder.

verses.latin: Cumque habitaret in illa regione, abiit Ruben, et dormivit cum Bala concubina patris sui: quod non latuit patrem suum. Erant autem filii Jacob duodecim.
verses.english: While Jacob was dwelling in that region, Reuben went and slept with Bilhah, his father's concubine – a grave sin that deeply dishonored his father. This act did not escape Jacob's knowledge, and it would have serious consequences later. Now, the sons of Jacob were twelve in number.

verses.latin: Filii Liae: Ruben primogenitus, et Simeon, et Levi, et Judas, et Issachar, et Zabulon.
verses.english: The sons of Leah were: Reuben, the firstborn; and Simeon, and Levi, and Judah, and Issachar, and Zebulun.

verses.latin: Filii Rachel: Joseph, et Benjamin.
verses.english: The sons of Rachel were: Joseph, and Benjamin.

verses.latin: Filii Balae famulae Rachel: Dan, et Nephthali.
verses.english: The sons of Bilhah, Rachel's handmaid, were: Dan, and Naphtali.

verses.latin: Filii Zelphae famulae Liae: Gad, et Aser: hi sunt filii Jacob, qui nati sunt ei in Mesopotamia Syriae.
verses.english: The sons of Zilpah, Leah's handmaid, were: Gad, and Asher. These are the sons of Jacob who were born to him in Mesopotamia of Syria, in the land of Paddan-Aram.

verses.latin: Venit quoque Jacob ad Isaac patrem suum in Mambre, civitatem Arbee, haec est Hebron, in qua peregrinatus est Abraham et Isaac.
verses.english: And Jacob also came to his father Isaac at Mamre, the city of Arba – which is Hebron. This was the place where both Abraham and Isaac had lived as sojourners, continuing the patriarchs' journey of faith.

verses.latin: Fueruntque dies Isaac centum octoginta annorum.
verses.english: Isaac's life spanned one hundred and eighty years.

verses.latin: Consumptusque senio, et plenus dierum, mortuus est, et aggregatus est ad populum suum, defuntus a filiis suis Esau et Jacob.
verses.english: Worn out by old age and full of years, Isaac died and was gathered to his people – a phrase indicating his peaceful passing into the afterlife. He was buried by his sons Esau and Jacob, marking a moment of reconciliation for them.

verses.latin: Haec sunt generationes Esau, ipse est Edom.
verses.english: This is the family line of Esau, who is also known as Edom.

verses.latin: Esau accepit uxores suas de filiabus Chanaan: Ada filiam Elon Hethaei, et Oolibama filiam Ana filiae Sebeon Hevaei:
verses.english: Esau took his wives from among the daughters of Canaan: Ada, the daughter of Elon the Hittite; and Oholibamah, the daughter of Ana, who was the daughter of Zibeon the Hivite.

verses.latin: Basemath quoque filiam Ismahel, sororem Nabaioth.
verses.english: Also Basemath, the daughter of Ishmael, who was the sister of Nebaioth.

verses.latin: Nati sunt autem Esau filii hi: Eliphaz de Ada, Raguel de Basemath.
verses.english: These were the sons born to Esau: Eliphaz was born from Ada, and Reuel from Basemath.

verses.latin: Porro de Oolibama nata sunt: Jehus, et Ihelon, et Core. Hi filii Esau, qui nati sunt ei in terra Chanaan.
verses.english: Also, from Oholibamah were born: Jeush, Jaalam, and Korah. These are the sons of Esau, who were born to him in the land of Canaan.

verses.latin: Tulit autem Esau uxores suas et filios et filias, et omnem animam domus suae, et substantiam, atque pecora, et cuncta quae habere poterat in terra Chanaan: et abiit in alteram regionem, secedens a fratre suo Jacob.
verses.english: Esau took his wives, his sons and daughters, and all the people of his household, along with all his possessions, his livestock, and everything he had acquired in the land of Canaan. And he went to another region, moving away from his brother Jacob.

verses.latin: Divites enim erant valde, et simul habitare non poterant: nec sustinebat eos terra peregrinationis eorum prae multitudine pecorum.
verses.english: Indeed, they were so wealthy that they could not live together in the same place. The land where they were staying as temporary residents could not support them both because of their many livestock.

verses.latin: Habitavitque Esau in monte Seir, ipse est Edom.
verses.english: So Esau settled in Mount Seir. He is also known as Edom, and this region became known by his name.

verses.latin: Hae sunt generationes Esau patris Edom in monte Seir:
verses.english: This is the family line of Esau, the ancestor of Edom, who lived in Mount Seir:

verses.latin: Et haec nomina filiorum Esau: Eliphaz filius Adae uxoris Esau: Raguel filius Basemath uxoris Esau.
verses.english: These are the names of Esau's sons: Eliphaz, the son of Ada, Esau's wife; and Reuel, the son of Basemath, Esau's wife.

verses.latin: Fueruntque filii Eliphaz: Theman, Omar, Sophar, Gatham, Cenez.
verses.english: The sons of Eliphaz were: Teman, Omar, Zepho, Gatam, and Kenaz.

verses.latin: Et Thamna erat concubina Eliphaz filii Esau: quae peperit ei Amalec. Hi sunt filii Adae uxoris Esau.
verses.english: And Timna was a concubine of Eliphaz, Esau's son, and she bore Amalek to him. These were the descendants of Ada, Esau's wife.

verses.latin: Filii autem Raguel: Nahath, Zara, Samma, Meza. Hi fuerunt filii Basemath uxoris Esau.
verses.english: The sons of Reuel were: Nahath, Zerah, Shammah, and Mizzah. These were the descendants of Basemath, Esau's wife.

verses.latin: Nati sunt autem et isti filii Oolibamae filiae Ana filiae Sebeon uxoris Esau: quibus genuit Jehus, et Ihelon, et Core.
verses.english: These also were the sons of Oholibamah, daughter of Ana, who was the daughter of Zibeon—Esau's wife: to whom she bore Jeush, Jaalam, and Korah.

verses.latin: Hi sunt duces filiorum Esau: filii Eliphaz primogeniti Esau: dux Theman, dux Omar, dux Sophar, dux Cenez,
verses.english: These are the chiefs (or tribal leaders) from the sons of Esau: from the sons of Eliphaz, Esau's firstborn: Chief Teman, Chief Omar, Chief Zepho, Chief Kenaz,

verses.latin: dux Core, dux Gatham, dux Amalec. Hi duces Eliphaz in terra Edom: et hi filii Adae.
verses.english: Chief Korah, Chief Gatam, Chief Amalek. These are the chiefs from Eliphaz in the land of Edom, and these are the descendants of Ada.

verses.latin: Hi quoque filii Raguel filii Esau: dux Nahath, dux Zara, dux Samma, dux Meza. Hi duces Raguel in terra Edom: hi filii Basemath uxoris Esau.
verses.english: These also are the sons of Reuel, Esau's son: Chief Nahath, Chief Zerah, Chief Shammah, Chief Mizzah. These are the chiefs from Reuel in the land of Edom; these are the descendants of Basemath, Esau's wife.

verses.latin: Hi quoque filii Oolibamae uxoris Esau: dux Jehus, dux Ihelon, dux Core. Hi duces Oolibamae filiae Ana uxoris Esau.
verses.english: These also are the sons of Oholibamah, Esau's wife: Chief Jeush, Chief Jaalam, Chief Korah. These are the chiefs from Oholibamah, the daughter of Ana, Esau's wife.

verses.latin: Hi sunt filii Esau, et hi duces eorum: ipse est Edom.
verses.english: These are the sons of Esau, and these are their chiefs. He is Edom, and these are his family lines.

verses.latin: Hi sunt filii Seir Horraei, habitatores terrae: Lothan, et Sobal, et Sebeon, et Ana,
verses.english: These are the sons of Seir the Horite, the inhabitants of that land: Lotan, Shobal, Zibeon, and Anah,

verses.latin: et Dison, et Eser, et Disan. Hi duces Horraei filii Seir in terra Seir.
verses.english: and Dishon, and Ezer, and Dishan. These are the Horite chiefs, the sons of Seir, in the land of Seir.

verses.latin: Fueruntque filii Lothan: Horri, et Heman. Et soror Lothan, Thamna.
verses.english: The sons of Lotan were: Hori and Hemam. And Lotan's sister was Timna (the one who became Eliphaz's concubine).

verses.latin: Filii quoque Sobal fuerunt: Alvan, et Manahath, et Ebal, et Sophar, et Onam.
verses.english: The sons of Shobal were also: Alvan, Manahath, Ebal, Shepho, and Onam.

verses.latin: Hi quoque filii Sebeon: Aja, et Ana. Iste est Ana, qui invenit aquas calidas in solitudine, cum pasceret asinos Sebeon patris sui.
verses.english: The sons of Zibeon were also: Aiah and Anah. This is the same Anah who found hot springs in the desert while pasturing the donkeys of his father Zibeon.

verses.latin: Et filii Ana: Dison, et Oolibama filia Ana.
verses.english: The children of Anah were: Dishon and Oholibamah, Anah's daughter (who became Esau's wife).

verses.latin: Hi filii Dison: Hamdan, et Eseban, et Jethran, et Charan.
verses.english: The sons of Dishon were: Hemdan, Eshban, Ithran, and Cheran.

verses.latin: Hi quoque filii Eser: Balaan, et Zavan, et Acan.
verses.english: The sons of Ezer were also: Bilhan, Zaavan, and Akan.

verses.latin: Hi filii Disan: Us, et Aran.
verses.english: The sons of Dishan were: Uz and Aran.

verses.latin: Hi sunt duces Horraei: dux Lothan, dux Sobal, dux Sebeon, dux Ana,
verses.english: These are the Horite chiefs: Chief Lotan, Chief Shobal, Chief Zibeon, Chief Anah,

verses.latin: dux Dison, dux Eser, dux Disan. Hi duces Horraei, qui imperaverunt in terra Seir.
verses.english: Chief Dishon, Chief Ezer, Chief Dishan. These are the Horite chiefs who ruled in the land of Seir.

verses.latin: Hi sunt reges, qui regnaverunt in terra Edom, antequam haberent regem filii Israel.
verses.english: These are the kings who reigned in the land of Edom before any king reigned over the children of Israel.

verses.latin: Regnavitque in Edom Bela filius Beor, et nomen urbis ejus Denaba.
verses.english: Bela, the son of Beor, reigned in Edom. And the name of his city was Dinhabah.

verses.latin: Mortuus est autem Bela, et regnavit pro eo Jobab filius Zara de Bosra.
verses.english: When Bela died, Jobab, the son of Zerah, from Bozrah, reigned in his place.

verses.latin: Mortuo quoque Jobab, regnavit pro eo Husam de terra Themanorum.
verses.english: When Jobab also died, Husham, from the land of the Temanites, reigned in his place.

verses.latin: Hoc quoque mortuo, regnavit pro eo Adad filius Barad, qui percussit Madian in regione Moab: et nomen urbis ejus Avith.
verses.english: When he also died, Hadad, the son of Bedad, reigned in his place. He was the one who defeated Midian in the region of Moab. And the name of his city was Avith.

verses.latin: Cumque mortuus esset Adad, regnavit pro eo Semla de Masreca.
verses.english: When Hadad died, Samlah, from Masrekah, reigned in his place.

verses.latin: Hoc quoque mortuo, regnavit pro eo Saul de fluvio Rooboth.
verses.english: When he also died, Shaul, from Rehoboth on the River, reigned in his place.

verses.latin: Mortuoque Saul, regnavit pro eo Balanan filius Achobor.
verses.english: When Shaul died, Baal-hanan, the son of Achbor, reigned in his place.

verses.latin: Hic quoque mortuo, regnavit pro eo Adar, et nomen urbis ejus Phau: et uxoris ejus Mehetabel filia Matred filiae Mezaab.
verses.english: When he also died, Hadar reigned in his place. And the name of his city was Pau. His wife's name was Mehetabel, the daughter of Matred, who was the daughter of Me-zahab.

verses.latin: Haec sunt nomina ducum Esau in cognationibus suis, et locis, et vocabulis suis: dux Thamna, dux Alva, dux Jetheth,
verses.english: These are the names of the chiefs of Esau, listed according to their families, their places of dwelling, and their specific names: Chief Timna, Chief Alvah, Chief Jetheth,

verses.latin: Habitavit autem Iacob in terra Chanaan, in qua et pater ejus peregrinatus est.
verses.english: Jacob settled in the land of Canaan, which was the same land where his father had lived as a foreigner.

verses.latin: Hae sunt generationes Iacob. Joseph, cum sedecim annorum esset, pascebat gregem cum fratribus suis adhuc puer: et erat cum filiis Balae et Zelphae uxorum patris sui: accusavitque fratres suos apud patrem crimine pessimo.
verses.english: This is the family record of Jacob. Joseph was sixteen years old, and though still a boy, he was tending the flock with his brothers. He was working with the sons of Bilhah and Zilpah, who were his father's wives. Joseph reported very serious misconduct about his brothers to his father.

verses.latin: Israël autem diligebat Joseph super omnes filios suos, eo quod in senectute genuisset eum: et fecit ei tunicam polymitam.
verses.english: Israel (Jacob) loved Joseph more than all his other sons, because Joseph had been born to him in his old age. So Jacob made for him a long, intricately designed tunic.

verses.latin: Videntes autem fratres ejus, quod a patre plus omnibus fratribus suis diligeretur, oderant eum, nec poterant ei quidquam pacifice loqui.
verses.english: When his brothers saw that their father loved Joseph more than all of them, they hated him and could not speak a single peaceful word to him.

verses.latin: Accidit quoque, ut somnium videret Joseph, quod narravit fratribus suis: unde magis eum oderant.
verses.english: It happened that Joseph also had a dream, which he told his brothers about, and because of this, they hated him even more.

verses.latin: Dixitque ad eos: Audite somnium meum, quod vidi.
verses.english: And he said to them: "Listen to this dream that I had."

verses.latin: Putabam nos ligare manipulos in agro: et quasi consurgere manipulum meum, et stare, vestrosque manipulos circumstantes adorare manipulum meum.
verses.english: "I imagined us tying up sheaves of grain in the field. And it was as if my sheaf rose up and stood upright, and your sheaves gathered around it and bowed down to my sheaf."

verses.latin: Responderunt fratres ejus: Numquid rex noster eris? aut dominabimur tibi? Hinc igitur et ob somnia et sermones ejus, magis eum oderant.
verses.english: His brothers replied: "Will you truly be our king? Or will you really rule over us?" Because of his dreams and his words, they hated him even more.

verses.latin: Vidit quoque aliud somnium, quod narravit patri et fratribus suis, dicens: Vidi per somnium quasi solem et lunam, et stellas undecim adorare me.
verses.english: He also had another dream, which he told his father and his brothers, saying: "I dreamed that the sun and the moon and eleven stars were bowing down to me."

verses.latin: Quod cum patri suo et fratribus narrasset, increpavit eum pater suus, et dixit: Quid sibi vult hoc somnium, quod vidisti? Num ego et mater tua et fratres tui adorabimus te super terram?
verses.english: When he told this to his father and his brothers, his father scolded him and said: "What does this dream mean that you have seen? Will I and your mother and your brothers truly bow down to you on the earth?"

verses.latin: Inviderunt itaque ei fratres sui: pater vero rem tacitus considerabat.
verses.english: So his brothers envied him, but his father quietly considered the meaning of the matter.

verses.latin: Ierunt igitur fratres ejus, ut pascerent greges patris sui in Sichem.
verses.english: Therefore, his brothers went to pasture their father's flocks in Shechem.

verses.latin: Dixitque Israël ad Joseph: Fratres tui pascunt oves in Sichem: veni, mittam te ad eos. Quo respondente: Praesto sum,
verses.english: Then Israel said to Joseph: "Your brothers are pasturing the sheep in Shechem. Come, I will send you to them." And Joseph replied, "I am ready to go."

verses.latin: ait: Vade, et vide si cuncta prospere agantur erga fratres tuos et oves: et renuntia mihi quid agatur. Missus de valle Hebron venit Sichem.
verses.english: Jacob said: "Go, and see if all is well with your brothers and the sheep, and bring me back word of what is happening." So Joseph was sent from the valley of Hebron and came to Shechem.

verses.latin: Invenitque eum vir errantem in agro, et interrogavit quid quaereret.
verses.english: And a man found him wandering in the field and asked him what he was looking for.

verses.latin: Respondit: Fratres meos quaero: indica mihi ubi pascant greges.
verses.english: He replied: "I am looking for my brothers. Tell me where they are pasturing the flocks."

verses.latin: Dixitque ei vir: Recesserunt de loco isto: audivi autem eos dicentes: Eamus in Dothain. Perrexitque Joseph post fratres suos, et invenit eos in Dothain.
verses.english: The man said to him: "They have moved on from this place. I heard them saying, 'Let us go to Dothan.'" So Joseph went after his brothers and found them in Dothan.

verses.latin: Qui cum vidissent eum procul, antequam accederet ad illos, cogitaverunt eum occidere.
verses.english: When they saw him from a distance, before he came near them, they plotted to kill him.

verses.latin: Et mutuo loquebantur: Ecce somniator venit.
verses.english: And they said to one another: "Look, here comes the dreamer."

verses.latin: Nunc ergo venite, et occidamus eum, mittamusque in cisternam veterem: dicemusque: fera pessima devoravit eum: et tunc apparebit quid illi prosint somnia sua.
verses.english: "Now then, come, let us kill him and throw him into an old cistern. Then we can say, 'A terrible wild beast devoured him,' and we will see what good his dreams will do him."

verses.latin: Audiens autem Ruben, conabatur liberare eum de manibus eorum, et ait: Non interficiamus animam ejus:
verses.english: But Reuben heard this and tried to rescue him from their hands, saying: "Let us not take his life."

verses.latin: nec effundatis sanguinem, sed mittite eum in cisternam hanc, quae est in solitudine, et manus vestras servate innoxias. Hoc autem dicebat, volens eripere eum de manibus eorum, et reddere patri suo.
verses.english: "Do not shed his blood, but throw him into this cistern, which is in the wilderness, and keep your hands free of his blood." Reuben said this intending to rescue Joseph from their hands and return him to his father.

verses.latin: Igitur ut venit ad fratres suos, statim nudaverunt eum tunica, quam habebat, polymita:
verses.english: Therefore, when Joseph came to his brothers, they immediately stripped him of the tunic he was wearing, the intricately designed tunic.

verses.latin: et mittentes in veterem cisternam, quae aquam non habebat.
verses.english: And they threw him into the old cistern, which had no water in it.

verses.latin: Et sedentes ut comederent panem, viderunt Ismahelitas viatores venire de Galaad, et camelos eorum portare aromata, et resinam, et stacten in Aegyptum.
verses.english: And as they sat down to eat bread, they saw Ishmaelite travelers coming from Gilead, their camels carrying spices, balm, and myrrh, on their way to Egypt.

verses.latin: Dixitque Judas fratribus suis: Quid nobis prodest, si occiderimus fratrem nostrum, et celaverimus sanguinem ipsius?
verses.english: Then Judah said to his brothers: "What benefit is it to us if we kill our brother and conceal his blood?"

verses.latin: melius est ut vendatur Ismahelitis, et manus nostrae non polluantur: frater enim noster est et caro nostra. Acquieverunt fratres.
verses.english: "It is better that he be sold to the Ishmaelites, so that our hands are not defiled by his blood. After all, he is our brother and our own flesh." His brothers agreed.

verses.latin: Et praetereuntibus Madianitis negotiatoribus, extrahentes Joseph de cisterna, vendiderunt Ismahelitis viginti argenteis: qui duxerunt eum in Aegyptum.
verses.english: As Midianite merchants passed by, they pulled Joseph out of the cistern and sold him to the Ishmaelites for twenty pieces of silver. These Ishmaelites then took him to Egypt.

verses.latin: Reversus itaque Ruben ad cisternam, non invenit puerum: et scissis vestibus,
verses.english: When Reuben returned to the cistern and did not find the boy, he tore his clothes in anguish.

verses.latin: nuntiavit fratribus, dicens: Puer non comparet, et ego quo ibo?
verses.english: He reported to his brothers, saying: "The boy is gone! And I, where can I go now?"

verses.latin: Tulerunt autem tunicam ejus, et in sanguinem haedi occisi tinxerunt:
verses.english: Then they took Joseph's tunic and dipped it in the blood of a slaughtered goat.

verses.latin: mittentes qui ferrent ad patrem, et dicerent: Hanc invenimus: vide utrum tunica filii tui sit, an non.
verses.english: They sent the tunic to their father with the message: "We found this. See if it is your son's tunic or not."

verses.latin: Quam cum agnovisset, ait: Tunica filii mei est: fera pessima comedit eum, bestia devoravit Joseph.
verses.english: When he recognized it, he said: "It is my son's tunic! A terrible wild beast has eaten him; a beast has devoured Joseph."

verses.latin: Et scissis vestibus lugens filium plurimo tempore.
verses.english: And tearing his clothes, he mourned for his son for a very long time.

verses.latin: Congregatisque cunctis liberis ejus ut consolarentur patrem suum, noluit consolationem accipere, et ait: Descendam ad filium meum lugens in infernum. Persevavitque flens.
verses.english: All his children gathered to comfort their father, but he refused to be comforted and said: "I will go down to my son, mourning, into the underworld of the dead." And he continued weeping.

verses.latin: Interea Madianitae vendiderunt Joseph in Aegypto Putiphari eunucho pharaonis, magistro militum.
verses.english: Meanwhile, the Midianites sold Joseph in Egypt to Potiphar, an official of Pharaoh, who was the commander of the royal guard.

verses.latin: This verse is not present in the Clementine Vulgate for Genesis chapter 37.
verses.english: This verse is not present in the Clementine Vulgate for Genesis chapter 37.

verses.latin: This verse is not present in the Clementine Vulgate for Genesis chapter 37.
verses.english: This verse is not present in the Clementine Vulgate for Genesis chapter 37.

verses.latin: This verse is not present in the Clementine Vulgate for Genesis chapter 37.
verses.english: This verse is not present in the Clementine Vulgate for Genesis chapter 37.

verses.latin: This verse is not present in the Clementine Vulgate for Genesis chapter 37.
verses.english: This verse is not present in the Clementine Vulgate for Genesis chapter 37.

verses.latin: Eo tempore descendit Judas a fratribus suis, et divertit ad virum Odollamitem, nomine Hiram.
verses.english: At that time, Judah left his brothers. He turned aside and went to stay with a man from Adullam, whose name was Hirah.

verses.latin: Viditque ibi filiam viri Chanaanaei, nomine Sue: et accepit eam, et intravit ad illam.
verses.english: There he saw the daughter of a Canaanite man named Shuah. He took her as his wife and then went in to her.

verses.latin: Quae concepit et peperit filium, vocavitque nomen ejus Her.
verses.english: She conceived and bore a son, and Judah called his name Er.

verses.latin: Et rursum concipiens peperit filium, et appellavit nomen ejus Onan.
verses.english: Again she conceived and bore a son, and she called his name Onan.

verses.latin: Tertio quoque peperit filium, quem vocabulo Sela insignivit. Porro ipse erat in Chanaan, quando nata est.
verses.english: She bore a third son, whom she named Shelah. Judah himself was in Canaan when Shelah was born.

verses.latin: Accepit autem Judas uxorem Her primogenito suo, nomine Thamar.
verses.english: Then Judah took a wife for his firstborn son, Er. Her name was Tamar.

verses.latin: Et Her, primogenitus Judae, erat nequam in conspectu Domini: et interfectus est ab eo.
verses.english: But Er, Judah's firstborn, was wicked in the sight of the Lord, and the Lord put him to death.

verses.latin: Dixit ergo Judas ad Onan: Ingredere ad uxorem fratris tui, et sociare illi, ut suscites semen fratri tuo.
verses.english: Therefore, Judah said to Onan: 'Go in to your brother's wife and perform the duty of a brother-in-law to her, and raise up offspring for your brother.'

verses.latin: Sciens ille quod non sibi nasceretur semen, cum ingrederetur ad uxorem fratris sui, semen fundebat in terram, ne proles fratris nomine nasceretur.
verses.english: But Onan knew that the offspring would not be considered his own. So, when he went in to his brother's wife, he spilled his semen on the ground, so that he would not raise up offspring in his brother's name.

verses.latin: Et idcirco percussit eum Dominus, eo quod rem detestabilem faceret.
verses.english: And for this reason, the Lord struck him down, because he did such a detestable thing.

verses.latin: Dixit ergo Judas ad Thamar nurum suam: Viduata sede in domo patris tui, donec crescat Sela filius meus: sciens quod et ipse moreretur, sicut et fratres ejus. Illa abiit, et mansit in domo patris sui.
verses.english: Therefore, Judah said to Tamar, his daughter-in-law: 'Remain a widow in your father's house until my son Shelah grows up.' Judah was actually thinking that Shelah also might die, just as his brothers had. So, Tamar went and remained in her father's house.

verses.latin: Post multos autem dies mortua est filia Sue uxor Judae: transactoque luctu, ascendit Judas in Thamnatha ad tonsores ovium suarum, ipse et Hiras pastor gregis sui, Odollamites.
verses.english: After many days, Shuah's daughter, Judah's wife, died. When the period of mourning was over, Judah went up to Timnah to his sheep shearers, along with his friend Hirah, the Adullamite, who was the shepherd of his flock.

verses.latin: Nuntiatumque est Thamar, eo quod socer suus ascenderet in Thamnatha ad tondendas oves.
verses.english: And it was told to Tamar: 'Your father-in-law is going up to Timnah to shear his sheep.'

verses.latin: Quae depositis viduitatis vestimentis, assumpsit pallium, et mutavit cultum, seditque in bivio itineris, quod ducit ad Thamnatha: eo quod vidisset Sela adultum, et ipsa sibi non esset data viro.
verses.english: So, she took off her widow's garments, covered herself with a veil, and disguised herself. Then she sat at the fork in the road that leads to Timnah, because she saw that Shelah was grown up, yet she had not been given to him as a wife.

verses.latin: Cum eam vidisset Judas, arbitratus est scortum: quia operuerat vultum suum.
verses.english: When Judah saw her, he thought she was a harlot, because she had covered her face.

verses.latin: Et divertit ad eam, dicens: Sine ut ingrediar ad te: nesciens quod nurus sua esset. Quae respondit: Quid dabis mihi, ut ingrediar ad me?
verses.english: He turned aside to her on the way and said: 'Let me come in to you,' not knowing that she was his daughter-in-law. She answered: 'What will you give me if you come in to me?'

verses.latin: At ille: Mittam, inquit, de grege caprum de hœdis. Rursum illa: Dabis, ait, mihi pignus, donec mittas?
verses.english: He answered: 'I will send you a young goat from the flock.' She replied: 'Will you give me a pledge until you send it?'

verses.latin: Respondit Judas: Quid vis tibi dari pignoris? At illa: Annulum tuum, et armillam, et baculum, quo niteris, inquit. Tribuit quae petierat, et intravit ad eam: quae concipiens, peperit ex eo.
verses.english: Judah said: 'What pledge shall I give you?' She answered: 'Your signet ring, your bracelet, and your staff that is in your hand.' So he gave her what she asked, and went in to her. And she conceived by him.

verses.latin: Et statim cum recessisset, consurgens abiit, et depositis ornatibus, viduitatis vestimentis induta est.
verses.english: As soon as he had departed, she rose and went away, and taking off her disguise, she put on her widow's garments again.

verses.latin: Judas autem misit hœdum caprarum per pastorem suum, Odollamitem, ut reciperet pignus quod dederat mulieri. Quem cum non invenisset,
verses.english: Then Judah sent the young goat by his friend Hirah, the Adullamite shepherd, so that he might retrieve the pledge from the woman. But Hirah could not find her.

verses.latin: interrogavit homines loci illius: Ubi est meretrix quae sedebat in bivio? Responderunt: Non fuit in loco isto meretrix.
verses.english: He asked the men of that place: 'Where is the harlot who was sitting at the fork in the road?' They answered: 'There has been no harlot in this place.'

verses.latin: Reversusque ad Judam, ait illi: Non inveni eam: sed et homines loci illius dixerunt mihi, non sedisse ibi meretricem.
verses.english: So, Hirah returned to Judah and said to him: 'I could not find her. Moreover, the men of that place told me that there had been no harlot sitting there.'

verses.latin: Dixit Judas: Habeat sibi, ne forte irridemur: ego quidem misi hœdum, et tu non invenisti eam.
verses.english: Judah said: 'Let her keep the items then, lest we become a laughingstock. I sent the young goat, and you could not find her.'

verses.latin: Post tres fere menses nuntiaverunt Judae, dicentes: Moecata est Thamar nurus tua, et ecce utero patet. Cui ait Judas: Educite illam, ut comburatur.
verses.english: About three months later, it was told to Judah: 'Your daughter-in-law Tamar has committed harlotry, and behold, she is found to be with child.' Judah said: 'Bring her out, that she may be burned.'

verses.latin: Cumque duceretur ad supplicium, misit ad socerum suum, dicens: De cujus sunt haec, ejus ego sum gravida. Cognosce, cujus sit annulus, et armilla, et baculus iste.
verses.english: As she was being led out to be executed, she sent to her father-in-law, saying: 'By the man to whom these things belong, by him I am pregnant.' She added: 'Please recognize whose signet ring, bracelet, and staff these are.'

verses.latin: Quibus recognitis, ait Judas: Justior me est: quia non dedi illam Sela filio meo. Et ultra non cognovit eam.
verses.english: When Judah recognized them, he said: 'She is more righteous than I, because I did not give her to my son Shelah.' And he did not lie with her again.

verses.latin: Tempore autem partus, apparuerunt gemini in utero ejus.
verses.english: Now, at the time of her delivery, it was discovered that she had twins in her womb.

verses.latin: Et cum pareret, unus protulit manum: in qua obstetrix ligavit filum coccineum, dicens: Iste primus egredietur.
verses.english: And as she was giving birth, one of the babies put out a hand. The midwife tied a scarlet thread on its hand, saying: 'This one will come out first.'

verses.latin: At ille retrahens manum, egressus est frater ejus: et dixit obstetrix: Quare divisa est de te maceria? et ob hanc causam vocavit nomen ejus Phares.
verses.english: But he drew back his hand, and then his brother came out. And the midwife said: 'Why have you made a breach for yourself?' So, for this reason, his name was called Perez.

verses.latin: Post quem egressus est frater ejus, in cujus manu erat signum coccineum: et appellavit nomen ejus Zara.
verses.english: After him, his brother came out, on whose hand was the scarlet thread. And his name was called Zerah.

verses.latin: Ioseph igitur deductus est in Aegyptum, emique illum fecit Putiphar eunuchus Pharaonis, princeps militum Aegyptiorum, de manu Ismahelitarum, a quibus deductus erat.
verses.english: Joseph had been brought to Egypt. Potiphar, an officer of Pharaoh and captain of the royal guard—not necessarily a eunuch in the literal sense, but a high-ranking court official—bought him from the Ishmaelites who had brought him there.

verses.latin: Fuit autem Dominus cum eo, et erat vir in cunctis prospere agens: habitabatque in domo domini sui Aegyptii.
verses.english: The Lord was with Joseph, and he prospered in all that he did. He lived in the house of his Egyptian master.

verses.latin: Qui videns Dominum esse cum illo, et omnia opera eius dirigere in manu illius,
verses.english: Potiphar saw that the Lord was with Joseph, and that God guided all of Joseph’s work to success.

verses.latin: dedit ei gratiam in conspectu suo, et ministrabat ei: et praeposuit eum domui suae, et universae rei familiaris suae.
verses.english: Because of this, Joseph found favor with Potiphar and became his personal attendant. Potiphar placed Joseph in charge of his entire household and all his possessions.

verses.latin: Ex quo autem constituit eum super domum suam et super cuncta quae habebat, benedixit Dominus domui Aegyptii propter Ioseph: et multiplicavit benedictionem in omni re, quae ad eum pertinebat, tam in aedificiis quam in agris.
verses.english: From the moment Potiphar appointed Joseph over his house and over all that he owned, the Lord blessed the Egyptian’s household because of Joseph. The Lord’s blessing multiplied everything that belonged to Potiphar, both in his house and in his fields.

verses.latin: Nec ultra quicquam scivit, nisi panem quo vescebatur. Erat autem Ioseph pulchra facie, et decorus aspectu.
verses.english: Potiphar no longer had to worry about anything, except the food he ate. Joseph was handsome in face and appearance.

verses.latin: Post multa itaque tempora injecit domina sua oculos suos in Ioseph, et ait: Dormi mecum.
verses.english: After a long time, Potiphar’s wife cast her eyes upon Joseph and said, "Sleep with me."

verses.latin: Qui renuit, et ait ad eam: Ecce dominus meus non novit quid habeat in domo sua, et omnia quae possidet, tradidit mihi:
verses.english: But Joseph refused, and said to her, "Look, my master does not know what he has in his house, and he has entrusted everything he owns to me."

verses.latin: nec quisquam major est in domo hac, quam ego: nec quicquam mihi denegavit praeter te, quae uxor ejus es: quomodo ergo possum hoc malum facere, et peccare in Deum meum?
verses.english: "No one in this house is greater than I am. He has not denied me anything except you, because you are his wife. How then could I do such a wicked thing and sin against my God?"

verses.latin: Cumque illi quotidie instaret, et ille nollet acquiescere, nec cubile quidem intrabat cum ea, nec ultra cum illa erat.
verses.english: She pressed him day after day, but he refused to agree. He would not even lie down with her or spend time with her anymore.

verses.latin: Accidit itaque ut quadam die intraret Ioseph domum, et operis quicquam faceret: nullusque hominum ex servis in aedibus erat.
verses.english: So one day Joseph went into the house to do his work, and none of the household servants were inside.

verses.latin: At illa apprehendit pallium ejus, dicens: Dormi mecum. Qui relicto in manu illius pallio, fugit, et egressus est foras.
verses.english: But she grabbed his cloak, saying, "Sleep with me!" Joseph left his cloak in her hand, fled, and ran outside.

verses.latin: Vidensque mulier pallium in manibus suis, et se contemptam,
verses.english: When the woman saw that his cloak was in her hands and that he had run away,

verses.latin: vocavit homines domus suae, et ait ad eos: En introduxit vir meus homo Hebraeum, ut illuderet nobis: ingressus est ad me, dicens: Dormi mecum: cumque ego clamarem,
verses.english: she called her household servants and said to them, "Look! My husband brought this Hebrew man here to mock us. He came into my room, saying, 'Sleep with me!' And when I screamed,"

verses.latin: et ille audisset vocem meam, quod inclamarem, reliquit pallium apud me, et fugit foras.
verses.english: "and he heard my voice crying out, he left his cloak with me and ran outside."

verses.latin: Deposuit ergo pallium juxta se, donec veniret dominus domus, et domum rediret.
verses.english: So she laid his cloak beside her until her husband came home.

verses.latin: Locuta est ad eum juxta eadem verba, dicens: Ingressus est ad me servus Hebraeus, quem adduxisti, ut illuderet mihi:
verses.english: She spoke to him with the very same words, saying, "The Hebrew servant whom you brought to us came in to mock me."

verses.latin: cumque audisset me vociferantem, reliquit pallium apud me, et fugit foras.
verses.english: "And when he heard me crying out, he left his cloak with me and fled outside."

verses.latin: His auditis dominus Josephi, et maxime quod eadem verba audisset ab uxore sua, quibus sibi referebat: iratus nimis,
verses.english: When Joseph’s master heard his wife’s words—especially hearing the exact same story she told him—he became very angry.

verses.latin: tradidit eum in carcerem, ubi vincti regis custodiebantur, et erat ibi clausus.
verses.english: So he had Joseph thrown into the prison where the king’s prisoners were held. And there Joseph remained, shut away.

verses.latin: Fuit autem Dominus cum Ioseph, et extendens ad eum misericordiam, dedit illi gratiam in conspectu principis carceris.
verses.english: But the Lord was with Joseph, and He extended His mercy to him, granting him favor in the eyes of the prison warden.

verses.latin: Qui et carceris principem constituit super universos vinctos, qui in custodia tenebantur: et quidquid fieret, sub ejus ordinatione agebatur.
verses.english: The warden put Joseph in charge of all the prisoners who were held in custody. Whatever needed to be done there was done under Joseph’s supervision.

verses.latin: Nec quicquam diligentius inquirebat princeps carceris, eo quod totum ejus arbitrio cuncta commissa essent: et Dominus esset cum illo, et omnia opera ejus dirigeret.
verses.english: The warden did not carefully oversee anything that was entrusted to Joseph, because the Lord was with Joseph, and the Lord directed all his work.

verses.latin: Post haec igitur accidit, ut peccarent duo eunuchi, pincerna regis Ægypti, et pistor, domino suo.
verses.english: After these events, it happened that two of Pharaoh’s officials, his chief cupbearer and his chief baker, offended their lord, the king of Egypt.

verses.latin: Iratusque Pharao contra eos, (etenim utrumque habebat sub pincerna et pistore),
verses.english: Pharaoh was angry with them both—the cupbearer and the baker—

verses.latin: misit eos in carcerem principis militum, in quo erat vinctus Ioseph.
verses.english: and he put them in the prison of the captain of the royal guard, the very place where Joseph was imprisoned.

verses.latin: Praecepitque princeps militum Ioseph, ut serviret illis. Qui ministrabat eis.
verses.english: The captain of the royal guard assigned Joseph to serve them, and he did so.

verses.latin: Aderant itaque in custodia multo tempore.
verses.english: So they remained in custody for a considerable time.

verses.latin: Videruntque ambo somnium nocte una, juxta interpretationem congruam sibi: uterque somnium suum.
verses.english: One night, both of them—the cupbearer and the baker—had a dream, each with its own specific meaning. Each man dreamed his own dream.

verses.latin: Ad quos cum Ioseph mane intrasset, et vidisset tristes:
verses.english: When Joseph came to them in the morning and saw that they were distressed,

verses.latin: interrogavit eos, dicens: Cur tristior est hodie solito vultus vester?
verses.english: he asked them, "Why are your faces sadder than usual today?"

verses.latin: Qui responderunt: Somnium vidimus, et non est qui interpretetur nobis.
verses.english: They answered, "We had dreams, and there is no one here to interpret them for us."

verses.latin: Dixitque ad eos Ioseph: Numquid non Dei est interpretatio? referte mihi quidquid somniastis.
verses.english: Joseph said to them, "Do not interpretations belong to God? Please, tell me what you dreamed."

verses.latin: Retulit igitur pincerna somnium suum: Dixi, inquit, somnio me videre vitem,
verses.english: So the chief cupbearer told Joseph his dream. He said, "In my dream, I saw a vine."

verses.latin: in qua erant tres propagines, crescere paulatim in gemmas, et post flores, uvas maturescere.
verses.english: "On the vine were three branches, which began to bud, then blossomed, and then ripened into clusters of grapes."

verses.latin: Tenui scyphum Pharaonis in manu mea: tulique uvas, et expressi in scyphum quem tenebam, et tradidi poculum Pharaoni.
verses.english: "I held Pharaoh’s cup in my hand. I took the grapes, pressed them into the cup I was holding, and then handed the cup to Pharaoh."

verses.latin: Respondens Ioseph: Haec est, inquit, interpretatio somnii: Tres propagines, tres adhuc dies sunt.
verses.english: Joseph answered, saying, "This is the interpretation of your dream: The three branches represent three days."

verses.latin: Post tres quippe dies elevabit Pharao caput tuum, et restituerit te ad pristinum gradum: dabisque ei scyphum juxta officium tuum, sicut prius facere consueveras.
verses.english: "Within three days, Pharaoh will lift up your head—meaning, he will restore you to your former position. You will then hand him his cup, just as you used to do when you were his cupbearer."

verses.latin: Tantum memento mei, cum tibi bene fuerit, et facias mecum misericordiam: ut suggeras Pharaoni de me, et educas me de isto carcere:
verses.english: "Only remember me when things go well for you, and show me kindness. Mention me to Pharaoh and get me out of this prison."

verses.latin: quia furto sublatus sum de terra Hebraeorum, et hic innocens in lacum missus sum.
verses.english: "For I was stolen away from the land of the Hebrews, and here I am, innocent, thrown into this pit of a prison."

verses.latin: His ita gestis, peccaverunt duo eunuchi, pincerna regis Ægypti, et pistor, domino suo regi.
verses.english: After all this, two royal officials of the King of Egypt—his chief butler and his chief baker—committed a sin against their lord, the king.

verses.latin: Iratusque Pharao contra eos, duos eunuchos, et majorem pincernarum, et pistorum principem, misit eos in carcerem, in quo erat vinctus Joseph, in domum præpositi militum.
verses.english: Pharaoh became very angry with these two royal officials, the chief butler and the chief baker. He had them sent to the prison in the house of the captain of the guard, which was the very place where Joseph was being held captive.

verses.latin: Tradiditque eos Joseph præpositus militum: qui et ministrabat eis. Omnia autem illic, quæ faciebant, ad ejus curam pertinebant.
verses.english: The captain of the guard placed these two officials under Joseph's care, and Joseph began to serve them. All the tasks performed in that part of the prison fell under Joseph's responsibility.

verses.latin: Post aliquantulum temporis, custodes carceris traditi sunt Joseph: et singuli per ordinem explere mandata illius. Et cum essent in custodia, Joseph ad eos frequentius ingrediebatur.
verses.english: For some time, these men were kept under Joseph's watch. Joseph visited them frequently while they were in custody, ensuring they were served as instructed.

verses.latin: Viditque uterque somnium nocte una, juxta interpretationem pertinentem ad se: pincerna et pistor regis Ægypti, qui erant vincti in custodia.
verses.english: One night, both the butler and the baker, who were prisoners of the King of Egypt, each had a dream. Each dream held a specific interpretation for the one who dreamed it.

verses.latin: Ad quos cum introisset Joseph mane, et vidisset eos tristes,
verses.english: When Joseph came to them in the morning, he noticed that both of them looked sad and troubled.

verses.latin: interrogavit eos dicens: Cur tristis est hodie solito vultus vester?
verses.english: So he asked them, "Why do you both look so much sadder than usual today?"

verses.latin: Qui responderunt: Somnium vidimus, et non est qui interpretetur. Dixitque ad eos Joseph: Numquid non Dei est interpretatio? referte mihi quod vidistis.
verses.english: They answered him, saying, "We both had dreams, and there is no one here to interpret them for us." Joseph then said to them, "Doesn't the power to interpret dreams belong to God alone? Please tell me your dreams, and I will seek His understanding."

verses.latin: Narravit ergo primus pincernarum somnium suum, dicens: Videbam coram me vitem,
verses.english: So the chief butler told Joseph his dream, saying, "In my dream, I saw a vine directly in front of me.

verses.latin: in qua erant tres propagines, crescere paulatim in gemmas, et post flores, uvas maturescere.
verses.english: On this vine, there were three branches. As I watched, it slowly budded, then blossomed, and finally, ripe grapes appeared on the clusters.

verses.latin: Calicemque Pharaonis in manu mea: et tuli uvas, et expressi in calicem quem tenebam, et dedi poculum Pharaoni.
verses.english: I held Pharaoh's cup in my hand. I took the grapes, squeezed their juice directly into the cup I was holding, and then presented the drink to Pharaoh."

verses.latin: Respondit Joseph: Hæc est interpretatio somnii: tres propagines, tres adhuc dies sunt:
verses.english: Joseph replied, "This is the meaning of your dream: the three branches represent three days from now.

verses.latin: post tres enim dies, levabit Pharao caput tuum, et restituet te in gradum pristinum: dabisque ei calicem juxta officium tuum, sicut prius facere consueveras.
verses.english: Within three days, Pharaoh will lift up your head, meaning he will restore you to your former position. You will then give him his cup, just as you used to do when you served as his butler before."

verses.latin: Tantum memento mei, cum tibi bene fuerit, et facias mecum misericordiam: ut suggeras Pharaoni, et educas me de isto carcere:
verses.english: "Only remember me when things go well for you. Show kindness to me by mentioning me to Pharaoh so that you can get me out of this prison.

verses.latin: quoniam furto sublatus sum de terra Hebræorum, et hic innocens in lacum missus sum.
verses.english: For I was stolen away from the land of the Hebrews, and even here, I have done nothing to deserve being thrown into this pit."

verses.latin: Videns pistor quod prudenter interpretatus esset, ait: Et ego somnium vidi: quod tria canistra farinæ haberem super caput meum:
verses.english: When the chief baker saw that Joseph had interpreted the dream so skillfully, he said, "I also had a dream. In my dream, I had three baskets of baked goods on my head.

verses.latin: et in uno canistro quod erat in medio, omnis cibi genera, quibus vesci solet Pharao, avesque comedere de canistro.
verses.english: In the topmost basket, there were all kinds of baked goods that Pharaoh usually eats, and the birds were eating them out of the basket on my head."

verses.latin: Respondit Joseph: Hæc est interpretatio somnii: tria canistra, tres adhuc dies sunt:
verses.english: Joseph responded, "This is the interpretation of your dream: the three baskets represent three days from now.

verses.latin: post tres dies auferet Pharao caput tuum, et suspendet te in ligno: et lacerabunt volucres carnes tuas.
verses.english: Within three days, Pharaoh will lift off your head, meaning he will execute you and hang your body on a tree. Then the birds of the sky will tear at your flesh."

verses.latin: Factum est autem tertio die, dies natalis Pharaonis: qui faciens grande convivium cunctis servis suis, recordatus est inter pincernas et pistores.
verses.english: And so it happened that on the third day, which was Pharaoh's birthday, he gave a great feast for all his servants. At this feast, he remembered the chief butler and the chief baker.

verses.latin: Et restituit officio suo pincernarum principem, et rursum poculum dedit Pharaoni:
verses.english: He restored the chief butler to his office, and once again the butler presented the cup to Pharaoh.

verses.latin: pistorum vero principem suspendit, sicut interpretatus fuerat eis Joseph.
verses.english: But he had the chief baker hanged, just as Joseph had interpreted their dreams for them.

verses.latin: Et tamen non est recordatus pincerna Josephi, sed oblitus est ejus.
verses.english: Despite this, the chief butler did not remember Joseph. Instead, he completely forgot about him.

verses.latin: Post annorum duorum spatium, Pharao vidit somnium: putabat se stare super flumen,
verses.english: After two full years had passed, Pharaoh had a dream. He dreamt he was standing by the Nile River,

verses.latin: et ecce de flumine ascendebant septem boves pulchrae et crassae: et pascebantur in locis palustribus.
verses.english: And suddenly, in his dream, seven beautiful, well-fed cows came up out of the river. They were grazing in a marshy place.

verses.latin: Aliæ quoque septem emergebant de flumine, foedæ et macilentæ, et pascebantur juxta priores in ipsa fluminis ripa:
verses.english: Then, seven other cows emerged from the river, but these were ugly and scrawny. They began to graze right next to the beautiful cows on the riverbank.

verses.latin: devoraveruntque pulcherrimas et crassissimas. Expergefactus Pharao,
verses.english: The ugly and scrawny cows then devoured the seven beautiful, well-fed cows. Pharaoh woke up from his dream.

verses.latin: rursum dormivit, et vidit alterum somnium: Septem spicæ pullulabant in culmo uno plenae atque pulcherrimæ.
verses.english: He then fell asleep again and had another dream. In this dream, seven heads of grain, full and beautiful, were growing on a single stalk.

verses.latin: Aliæ quoque septem spicæ tenues et percussæ uredine, oriebantur in altero culmo:
verses.english: Then, seven other heads of grain, thin and scorched by the east wind, grew up on a different stalk.

verses.latin: quae devoraverunt omnem pulchritudinem priorum. Expergefactus Pharao, post somnum intellexit esse divinum.
verses.english: These thin heads of grain devoured all the beauty of the full, first heads of grain. Pharaoh woke up from his sleep and understood that these dreams were from God.

verses.latin: Facto mane, expavefactus, misit et accersivit omnes conjectores Aegypti et sapientes: et narravit illis somnium, nec erat qui interpretaretur.
verses.english: When morning came, Pharaoh was deeply troubled by the dream. He sent for all the magicians and wise men of Egypt, and he told them his dream, but none of them could interpret it for him.

verses.latin: Tunc demum reminiscens pistorum magister, ait: Confiteor peccatum meum.
verses.english: Then, the chief cupbearer, remembering Joseph, spoke up and said, 'I must confess my fault to you now.'

verses.latin: Cum iratus Pharao, jussisset me et principem pistorum poni in carcerem, in domo ducis satellitum:
verses.english: 'When Pharaoh was angry with me and the chief baker, you had us put in prison in the house of the captain of the guard.'

verses.latin: vidimus somnium una nocte, ego et ille: et singuli sicut aenigma rei, interpretati sumus.
verses.english: 'One night, both he and I each had a dream, and each of our dreams had a mysterious meaning.'

verses.latin: Erat ibi puer Hebræus, ejusdem ducis satellitum famulus: cui cum indicassemus somnia nostra, interpretatus est nobis.
verses.english: 'There was a young Hebrew man there, a servant of that same captain of the guard. When we told him our dreams, he interpreted them for us.'

verses.latin: Et sicut prædixerat, ita facta sunt: ego redditus sum officio meo, et ille suspensus est patibulo.
verses.english: 'And everything happened exactly as he predicted: I was restored to my position, and the other man was hanged.'

verses.latin: Continuo jussu regis eductum protinus de carcere, tonderunt: ac veste mutata, adduxerunt ad eum.
verses.english: Immediately, at the king's command, Joseph was quickly brought out of the prison dungeon. They shaved him and changed his clothes, then brought him to Pharaoh.

verses.latin: Cui ille ait: Vidi somnium, et nemo est qui edisserat: audivi autem quod tu prudentissime interpretaris.
verses.english: Pharaoh said to Joseph, 'I have had a dream, and there is no one who can interpret it for me. But I have heard that you are able to interpret dreams with great wisdom.'

verses.latin: Respondit Joseph: Absque me Deus respondebit prospera Pharaoni.
verses.english: Joseph answered Pharaoh, saying, 'It is not within my power, but God Himself will give Pharaoh a favorable answer.'

verses.latin: Narravit ergo Pharao, quod viderat: Putabam, inquit, me stare super ripam fluminis:
verses.english: So Pharaoh recounted what he had seen, saying, 'I dreamt that I was standing on the bank of the Nile River.'

verses.latin: et ecce septem boves de flumine ascendebant, pulchræ nimis, et crassissimæ: quæ, locis palustribus pabulatæ, manserunt juxta me.
verses.english: 'And suddenly, seven very beautiful and extremely well-fed cows came up out of the river. They grazed in the marshy places and remained standing near me.'

verses.latin: Et aliæ septem ascendebant tenues et macilentissimæ, et arida cute, quales in tota terra Aegypti nunquam ante vidimus:
verses.english: 'Then, seven other cows came up, thin and extremely scrawny, with dried-out hides. I have never seen such ugly cows in all the land of Egypt.'

verses.latin: quæ devoraverunt et consumpserunt priores, pingues et crassas.
verses.english: 'These scrawny cows devoured and consumed the first, fat, and beautiful cows.'

verses.latin: In quarum ventres cum intrassent, nihil apparuit in eis, quin potius tristes erant et macilentæ, sicut prius. Expergefactus sum.
verses.english: 'Even after they had eaten them, there was no sign in their appearance that they had eaten at all; they remained as gaunt and scrawny as before. Then I woke up.'

verses.latin: Et rursum vidi somnium: Septem spicæ pullulabant in culmo uno, plenæ et egregiæ.
verses.english: 'And again, I saw another dream: Seven heads of grain, full and excellent, were growing on a single stalk.'

verses.latin: Et aliæ septem oriebantur tenues et percussæ uredine, exiguo germine:
verses.english: 'Then, seven other heads of grain grew up, thin and scorched by the east wind, producing only meager kernels.'

verses.latin: quæ devoraverunt priorum pulchritudinem. Narravi conjectoribus, et nemo est qui edisserat.
verses.english: 'These thin heads of grain devoured the beauty of the first ones. I have told this to the magicians, but there is no one who can interpret it.'

verses.latin: Respondit Joseph: Somnium Pharaonis unum est: quæ facturus est Deus, ostendit Pharaoni.
verses.english: Joseph answered Pharaoh, 'Pharaoh's dreams are one and the same; God has revealed to Pharaoh what He is about to do.'

verses.latin: Septem boves pulchræ, et septem spicæ plenæ, septem anni sunt ubertatis: eadem quoque interpretatio est somnii.
verses.english: 'The seven beautiful cows and the seven full heads of grain represent seven years of abundant harvests. The interpretation of both dreams is the same.'

verses.latin: Septem quoque boves tenues atque macilentæ, quæ ascenderunt post eas: et septem spicæ tenues, et ustæ uredine, septem anni sunt famis venturæ:
verses.english: 'And the seven thin and scrawny cows that came up after them, as well as the seven thin heads of grain scorched by the east wind, represent seven years of famine that are coming.'
